column4: Die Schlacht von Kolberg zwischen 4. und 18. März 1945 war eine verbissene Häuserschlacht zwischen der Roten Armee und den deutschen Verteidigern der Stadt in Ostpommern. Die Deutschen konnten erfolgreich die meisten Soldaten und Flüchtlinge über die Ostsee evakuieren, bevor die Stadt schließlich am 18. März fiel.

column2: Victorious Battle of Sevastopol

The Siege of Sevastopol took place from 30 October 1941 to 4 July 1942 between German forces and those of the Red Army, the Black Sea Fleet and elements of the Red Air Force over the control for the main Soviet Black Sea Fleet naval base during the Second World War. It is notable for use of German heavy artillery during the siege.
column4: Die Belagerung von Sewastopol dauerte vom 30. Oktober 1941 bis zum 5. Juli 1942 zwischen deutschen Truppen und denen der Roten Armee, der Schwarzmeerflotte sowie Elementen der Roten Luftwaffe. Am 30. Oktober 1941 wurden 2 Infanteriedivisionen mit einer motorisierten Brigade zu einer schnellen Offensive Richtung Sewastopol eingesetzt. Die Deutschen versuchten, vom Norden, Nordosten und Osten in die Stadt einzudringen, wurden jedoch zurückgeschlagen. Sie kreisten die Stadt nun ein. Nach mehreren Angriffen, Bombardements und Gegenangriffen schlugen die Deutschen die Sowjets schließlich am 29. Juni 1942 und die Stadt fiel.

column2: Victorious Battle for Velikie Luki

The Velikiye Luki offensive operation was executed by the forces of the Red Army's Kalinin Front against the Wehrmacht’s 3rd Panzer Army during the Winter Campaign of 1942-1943 with the objective of liberating the Russian city of Velikie Luki as part of the northern pincer of the Rzhev-Sychevka Strategic Offensive Operation. It is particularly notable as an example of the failure of German operational combat in relieving an encirclement, similar to those employed at the Battle of Stalingrad.
column4: Die Offensive bei Velikiye Luki wurde von Truppen der Roten Armee gegen die deutsche 3. Panzerarmee im Winter von 1942-43. Besonders auffallend dabei ist der Vergleich mit der Schlacht um Stalingrad, wie dort gelang es den deutschen nicht, eingeschlossene Truppenteile aus einem Kessel zu entsetzen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Voronez

The Battle of Voronez took place from December 1941 to 6 July 1942. The city was defended by the troops of the 40th Army as part of the Valuiki-Rossosh Defensive Operation of the General of Army Nikolai Fyodorovich Vatutin's Southwestern Front. The German assault was conducted by the element of the 4th Panzer Army's forces of the Army Group South, commanded by General Hermann Hoth. Hoth, under strict instructions not to get bogged down in street-to-street fighting, the armoured units of the 4th Panzer Army partly captured Voronez on 6 July by occupying the western river-bank suburbs, however German troops were subjected to a Red Army counter-attack. The 4th Panzer Army was to be followed by the Sixth Army, and when Voronez was occupied the former was to wheel south-eastward and move down the right bank of the Don towards Stalingrad as part of Operation Blau. It took two days for infantry divisions from the Army Group South to reach Voronez to hold the line and free the Panzer troops.
column4: Die Schlacht von Voronez fand von Dezember 1941 bis 6. Juli 1942 statt. Die Stadt wurde von Truppen der russischen 40. Armee verteidigt gegen Elemente der deutschen 4. Panzerarmee, die von General Hermann Hoth geführt wurde. Hoth nahm Teile der Stadt ein, fürchtete jedoch einen Häuserkampf und wurde von einem Gegenangriff der Roten Armee überrascht. Aber die deutsche 6. Armee, die der 5. Panzerarmee folgte, konnte Voronez schließlich sichern und weiter gegen Stalingrad vorstoßen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Calais

The Battle of Calais took place from 22 May to 26 May 1940. When the German offensive was launched in May 1940, Calais was subjected to increasingly heavy bombing, which caused disruption to military movements. On 20 May, the Germans seized Abbeville on the River Somme, capturing the last bridges over the river before the sea, and effectively isolating the BEF in Flanders and Picardy, cut off from its logistic bases. The War Office in Britain hastily despatched troops to the Canal ports, in case they were required either to re-supply the BEF or evacuate it. On the morning of 26 May, Calais Nord and the Citadel were pounded by artillery, and by 200 German bombers. About mid-afternoon, the Germans finally crossed the bridges over the canal and advanced into Calais Nord. On the other side of the harbour, they captured the Gare Maritime. The citadel was surrounded.
column4: Die Schlacht von Calais fand vom 22. bis 26. Mai 1940 statt als deutsche Truppen nach intensiven Luft- und Artillerieangriffen die Brücken über den Kanal bei Calais überschritten und gegen die Stadt worgingen. Bald war die Zitadelle eingeschlossen und kurz darauf war Calais von den Deutschen besetzt.

column2: Victorious Battle of Gazala

The Battle of Gazala was an important battle of the Second World War Western Desert Campaign, fought around the port of Tobruk in Libya from May 26 to June 21, 1942. The combatants on the Axis side were the Panzer Army Afrika, consisting of German and Italian units and commanded by the 'Desert Fox' Colonel-General Erwin Rommel, the Allied forces were the Eighth Army, commanded by Major General Neil Ritchie under the close supervision of the Commander-in-Chief Middle East, General Sir Claude Auchinleck. The battle ended in a resounding victory for the Axis. However, devoid of effective armoured forces in subsequent battles, Rommel was unable to pursue and decisively defeat the Eighth Army in Egypt.
column4: Die Schlacht von Gazala wasr eine wichtige Schlacht in der westlichen Wüste in Libyen zwischen 26. Mai und 21. Juni 1942. Die deutsche Panzerarmee Afrika unter dem Wüstenfuchs Erwin Rommel mit deutschen und italienischen Verbänden standen der britischen 8. Armee unter Major General Neil Ritchie und General Sir Claude Auchinleck gegenüber. Der Ausgang der Schlacht war ein Erfolg der Achse, die jedoch dabei die meisten ihrer Panzer verloren und daher die Briten nicht verfolgen konnten.

column2: Victorious Battle of Kassel

The Battle of Kassel was a four-day struggle between the U.S. Army and the German Army in April 1945 for Kassel, a medium-sized city northeast of Frankfurt am Main. The battle resulted as the U.S. Third Army pushed northeast from the region of Frankfurt and Mainz. The battle opened on April 1, 1945 and ended with an American victory three days later. Opposing the Third Army's 80th Infantry Division were an infantry replacement battalion, some heavy tanks, and anti-aircraft guns. Although the Germans gave battle at Kassel, their army was on the brink of collapse as the Western Allies and the Red Army made deep inroads into Germany. The defence of Kassel did not materially impede the Allied advance, and, one month after the battle ended, Germany was forced to capitulate.
column4: Die Schlacht von Kassel war ein viertägiges Gefecht zwischen der US Army und der deutschen Wehrmacht im April 1945. Die 3. US Army griff am 1. April 1945 die Stadt an, die von einem Infanterie-Ersatzbatalion, einigen schweren Panzern und Flak verteidigt wurde gegen die 80. US Infanteriedivision. Die Schlacht fand kurz vor dem Ende des Krieges statt und beeinflusste den Kriegsverlauf in keiner Weise.

column2: Victorious Battle of Tornio

The Battle of Tornio took place from October 1 to October 8, 1944 and was the first major engagement between Nazi Germany and Finland in the Lapland War. The Finnish Infantry Regiment 11 landed unopposed at Röyttä harbour and took the town of Tornio the same day. The German troops in town were surrounded in a few pockets until they surrendered. Further landings in Tornio the next day came under attack of Stuka bombers of Luftwaffe, but was completed successfully despite casualties of 60 men. German counter attacks were repulsed with the aid of a battery of field artillery that was part of the second landing and fire support from Finnish gunboats. Due to lack of roads, the supplies to the troops around Kemi would have to be routed through Rovaniemi. This forced the Germans withdraw their units from Kemi. By October 8 the whole Kemi-Tornio area had been cleared.
column4: Die Schlacht von Tornio fand vom 1. bis 8. Oktober 1944 statt und war das erste große Gefecht zwischen deutschen und finnischen Truppen im Lapplandkrieg. Das finnische 11. Infanterieregiment landete nahe der Stadt und konnten die Deutschen Truppen einschließen und vernichten. Die Luftwaffe bombardierte die weiteren Landungen, die dennoch mit dem Verlust von 60 Mann durchgeführt wurden. Deutsche Gegenangriffe wurden abgewiesen und bis zum 8. Oktober war das Gebiet von Kemi-Tornio gesichtert.

column2: Victorious Battle of Malta

The Siege of Malta was a military campaign in the Mediterranean Theatre of World War II and took place from 1940 to 1942. The fight for the control of the strategically important island of Malta pitted the air forces and navies of Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany against the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy. From Malta, British air and sea forces could attack Axis ships transporting vital supplies and reinforcements from Europe to the Axis forces in North Africa. Malta was one of the most intensively bombed areas during the war. The German Luftwaffe and the Italian Regia Aeronautica flew a total of 3,000 bombing raids over a period of two years. Axis plans were made for Operation Herkules, an amphibious invasion of the island supported by airborne forces, but was never carried out. In the end, Allied convoys were able to supply and reinforce Malta, though at great cost. This played a major role in the eventual Allied victory in North Africa.
column4: Die Belagerung von Malta war eine Militärkampagne im Mittelmehrraum zwischen 1940 und 1942. Die Schlacht um die Kontrolle der strategischen Insel sah die Luftwaffe und Flotte von Italien und Deutschland auf der einen, die Royal Air Force und Royal Navy auf der anderen Seite. Von Malta aus konnten britische Luft- und Seeeinheiten Schiffe der Achse angreiffen, die wichtien Nachschub sowie Verstärkung für die Truppen in Nordafrika transportierten. Malta war eines der während des Krieges am meisten bombardierten Gebiete. Die deutsche Luftwaffe und die italienische Regia Aeronautica flogen insgesamt 3000 Bombenangriffe während der 2 Jahre. Die Achsenmächte planten Operation Herkules, die Invasion der Insel unterstützt durch eine Luftlandung, jedoch wurde diese niemals ausgeführt. Schlussendlich konnten alliierte Konvois Malta versorgen und verstärken, allerdings unter schweren Verlusten. Dies war ein wichtiger Beitrag zum alliierten Sieg in Nordafrika.

column2: Victorious Battle of Grudziadz

The Battle of Grudziadz took place from 1 September to 4 September 1939. It was a military engagement between German and Polish forces during the Invasion of Poland in 1939. The German XXI Corps assaulted the city on 1 September. The German 21st and 218th Infantry Divisions pushed back the Polish lines to the small river Ossa, east of Grudziadz. On 3 September elements of the German 45th Infantry Regiment managed to break into the town itself. The Germans held out there until the evening, but had to retreat when the Polish pressure increased. At the same time Boltuc received news that the Polish divisions on the western bank of the Vistula were facing defeat and the German forces had already crossed the Vistula in the south. This forced him to pull back his units in order to avoid being soon encircled. The Polish defenders destroyed the bridges over the Vistula and retreated to the southeast. The Germans occupied the city on 4 September.
column4: Die Schlacht von Grudziadz fand von 1. bis 4. September 1939 statt. Das deutsche XXI Korps griff die Stadt mit der 21. und 218. Infanteriedivision an und brach am 3. durch die polnischen Linien auf die Stadt durch, mussten sich jedoch über den Fluss Ossa zurückziehen. Die Polen mussten sich nach zerstörung der Vistulabrücken zurückziehen, nachdem deutsche Verbände bereits an mehreren anderen Stellen den Fluss überschritten hatten, um der Einkreisung zu entgehen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Jaroslaw

The Battle of Jaroslaw took place between September 10 and September 11, 1939, in the city of Jaroslaw on the San River. During the battle the Polish forces of General Stanislaw Maczek successfully held the river crossings in the town for two days against the Nazi German Wehrmacht, which was enough time for the Polish 10th Motorized Cavalry Brigade to cross the river and retreat further eastwards.
column4: Die Schlacht von Jaroslaw fand zwischen 10. und 11. September 1939 am Fluss San statt als General Stanislaw Maczek die Flussübergenge bei der Stadt 2 Tage lang gegen die deutschen Angreifer verteidigte, wodurch die 10. motorisierte Kavalleriebrigade sich über den Fluss zurückziehen konnte.

column2: Victorious Battle of Kaluszyn

The Battle of Kaluszyn, took place from September 11 to September 12, 1939. The German forces of the German 11th Infantry Division, who managed to take the town and surround the Polish forces, overran them. The Polish aim was to retake the town and break through the German encirclement before panzer reinforcements arrived and enemy resistance stiffened. The Polish forces managed to break through the positions of the enemy 44th Infantry Regiment. An order for the 4th squadron of the Polish 11th Uhlans Regiment to advance towards the town itself was mistakenly understood as an order of a cavalry charge and the squadron rushed towards the enemy positions. In the effect of the accidental charge the Poles broke through to the town. The Polish infantry followed into the breach in the German defences and by the early morning the town was liberated and the German division sent in retreat.
column4: Die Schlacht von Kaluszyn fand am 11. und 12. September 1939 statt als die deutsche 11. Infanteriedivision von polnischen Verbänden angegriffen wurden, die die Stadt zurückerobern wollten bevor deutsche Panzerverbände eintrafen. Der Angriff durch Kavallerie- und Infanterieverbände war erfolgreich und die Deutschen mussten sich zurückziehen und die Stadt den Polen überlassen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Lodz

The Battle of Lodz took place from September 6 to 8, 1939. By September 6, two Wehrmacht army groups had linked up at Lodz. While Lodz was under the control of the Wehrmacht, the 4th Panzer Division continued to advance east towards Warsaw. By September 8, the German advance stalled at the gates of Warsaw. The Polish Army launched a counterattack between Lodz and Warsaw in hopes off cutting off the German army's supply lines and recapturing the city of Lodz. After three days of bitter fighting, Germany defeated the desperate Polish counterattack. The city of Lodz was occupied by Germany on September 8, 1939. Recognizing the failed counterattack, all Polish forces were ordered to fall back, regroup in Eastern Poland for a last stand, and wait for aid from Great Britain and France, which would never come.
column4: Die Schlacht von Lodz fand am 6. bis 8. September 1939 statt. 2 deutsche Heeresgruppen trafen hier zusammen und nahmen die Stadt ein, jedoch starteten die Polen einen Gegenangriff auf die Stadt um die Nachschublinien der deutschen Truppen abzuschneiden. Nach 3 Tagen verzweifelter Angriffe mussten die Polen den Plan aufgeben und alle ihre Verbände nach Ostpolen zurückziehen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Lwow

The Battle of Lwow was a battle for the control over the Polish city of Lwow between the Polish Army, the invading Wehrmacht and the Red Army. Soviet armoured units were pushed back after a short fight. The Soviet forces completed the encirclement of the city and joined up with the German army besieging Lwow from the west. The same day the German commander sent his envoy and demanded that the city be surrendered to Germany. When the Polish envoy replied that he had no intention of signing such a document, he was informed that the general assault was ordered on September 21 and that the city would most surely be taken. However, on September 20 the Germans left their positions to the north and south of the city, and were replaced with Soviet soldiers. On September 22, 1939, the act of surrender was signed in the suburb of Winniki.
column4: Die Belagerung von Lwow war eine Schlacht zwischen polnischen, russischen und deutschen Truppen um die Kontrolle der Stadt Lwow. Sowjetische Panterspitzen wurden nach einem kurzen Gefecht zurückgeschlagen. Russische Truppen schlossen die Stadt dann ein und nahmen Verbindung mit den Deutschen auf, die die Stadt vom Westen belagerten. Der Deutsche Kommandeur schickte einen Unterhändler und verlangte die Übergabe der Stadt an Deutschland. Als die Polen dieses ablehnten wurden sie informiert, dass der Generalangriff für den 21. September geplant war und die Stadt sicher gestürmt werden würde. Aber am 20. verließen die Deutschen ihre Positionen im Westen und Süden der Stadt, die von russischen Truppen besetzt wurden. Am 22. September 1939 wurde die Kapitulation unterzeichnet.

column2: Victorious Battle of Radom

The Battle of Radom was part of the Invasion of Poland during the Second World War. It lasted from 8 September 1939 to 9 September 1939. Polish troops of the Prusy Army, under the Colonel Muzyka, defended the city of Ilza and road from Sandomierz to Radom. The Polish infantry were eventually defeated by German armoured troops and made their last stand in an ancient castle on a hill near Ilza.
column4: Die Schlacht von Radom während der deutschen Invasion von Polen dauerte vom 8.-9. September 1939. Polnische Truppen unter Colonel Muzyka verteidigten die Stadt Ilza und die Straße nach Radom, wurden jedoch von deutschen Panzertruppen überrannt und nach einem letzten Gefecht in einer historischen Burg in der Gegend aufgerieben.

column2: Victorious Battle of Hong Kong

The Battle of Hong Kong took place during the Pacific campaign of World War II. It began on 8 December 1941 and ended on Christmas Day with Hong Kong, then a Crown colony, surrendering to the Empire of Japan.
column4: Die Schlacht von Hong Kong begann am 8. Dezember und bis zum Weihnachtstag konnten die Japaner die britische Kronkolonie vollständig besetzen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Ambon

The Battle of Ambon took place from 30 January to 3 February 1942. Dutch and Australian forces resisted a Japanese invasion. From 6 January onwards, Japanese aircraft attacked Ambon. Allied aircraft made some sorties against the approaching Japanese fleet, with little success. The naval aviation base at Halong was soon rendered unusable by Japanese air raids, and was abandoned by the Dutch and US navies in mid-January. The first land attack on Laha occurred on the afternoon of 31 January. Japanese forces were also approaching the town of Ambon from the southwest and on 31 January, the Japanese captured the town. By the morning of 3 February, the Australians around Eri were struggling to cope with increasing air and naval attacks, wounded Australians, the influx of Dutch personnel, diminishing supplies and widespread fatigue. A Japanese flag had been seen flying on the other side of the bay, at Laha. The Allied position at Kudamati was surrendered separately at midday.
column4: Die Schlacht von Ambon fand am 30. Jänner bis 3. Februar 1942 statt als holländische und australische Truppen der japanischen Invasion Widerstand leisteten. Seit dem 6. Februar flog die japanische Luftwaffe Angriffe auf Ambon. Alliierte Flieger versuchten, die Invasionsflotte anzugreifen, hatten aber wenig Erfolg. Die erste Landung bei Laha am Nachmittag des 31. Jänner war erfolgreich und bald eroberten die Japaner auch Ambon. Die alliierte Positionen bei Kudamati kapitulierten mittags am 3. Februar.

column2: Victorious Battle of Balikpapan

The Battle of Balikpapan took place on 1 July 1945. The Australian 7th Division, composed of the 18th, 21st and 25th Infantry Brigades made an amphibious landing on the island of Borneo. Heavy bombing and shelling by Australian and US air and naval forces had preceded the landing. The Japanese were totally outnumbered and out gunned. Major operations had ceased by July 21. The 7th Division's casualties were significantly lighter than they had suffered in previous campaigns. Japan surrendered while the Australians were combing the jungle for stragglers. Following the surrender the three Brigades were committed to occupation duties until around February 1946. The 21st Brigade was detached to Makassar in the Celebes Islands to accept surrender of the Japanese forces, release POWs and maintain civil order.
column4: Die Schlacht von Balikpapan fand am 1. Juli 1945 statt. Die australische 7. Division landete auf der Insel von Borneo nach schwerem Beschuss durch alliierte Luft- und Seestreitkräfte. Die Japaner waren stark unterlegen und bis zum 21. Juli waren die Operationen fast abgeschlossen und die Verluste der 7. Division waren viel leichter als in vorhergegangenen Operationen. Die Japaner kapitulierten kurz nach dem Ende der Schlacht.

column2: Victorious Battle of Beirut

The Battle of Beirut took place on 12 July 1941 and marked the end of hostilities in the Syria-Lebanon campaign. On 8 July, even before the fall of Damour, the Vichy French commander, General Henri Dentz, had sought an armistice. At one minute past midnight on 12 July a ceasefire came into effect. For all intents and purposes, this ended the campaign and an armistice was signed on 14 July at the 'Sidney Smith Barracks' on the outskirts of the city of Acre. The triumphant entry of the Australian 7th Division into Beirut successfully established the Allied occupation of Lebanon. Beirut later became an important Allied base for Mediterranean naval operations.
column4: Die Schlacht von Beirut fand am 12. Juli 1941 statt. Sie war das letzte Gefecht in der Operation von Syrien-Libanon. Die Vichytruppen in der französischen Kolonie kapitulierten und ermöglichten den Briten die Sicherung des östleichen Mittelmeeres.

column2: Victorious Battle of Kranj

The Battle of Kranj took place from 9 February to 15 February 1942. The Japanese Army assaulted the northwestern front of the British colony of Singapore with a primary objective to secure a second beachhead after their successful assault at Sarimbun Beach on 8 February, in order to breach the Jurong-Kranj defence line as part of their southward thrust towards the heart of Singapore City. Defending the shoreline between the Kranj River and the Johor-Singapore Causeway was the Australian 27th Brigade. On 10 February the Japanese forces suffered their heaviest losses while moving up the Kranj River, which caused them to panic and nearly aborted the operation. However, a series of miscommunications and withdrawals by Allied forces in the ensuing battles allowed the Japanese to swiftly gain strategic footholds, which eventually led to the fall of Singapore on 15 February 1942.
column4: Die Schlacht von Kranj fand vom 9. bis 15. Februar 1942 statt. Die japanische Armee griff die nordwestliche Front vor Singapur mit dem Ziel an, einen zweiten Landekopf nach der erfolgreichen Landung in der Sarimbunbucht am 8. Februar zu erhalten. Die australische 27. Brigade konnte den Japanern schwere Verluste zufügen und sie beinahe aufhalten, jedoch mussten sie schließlich die Verteidigungslinien räumen und am 15. Februar 1942 fiel Singapur schließlich.

column2: Victorious Battle of Wau

The Battle of Wau, 29–31 January 1943, was a battle in the New Guinea campaign of World War II. Forces of the Empire of Japan sailed from Rabaul and crossed the Solomon Sea and, despite Allied air attacks, successfully reached Lae, where they disembarked. Japanese troops then advanced overland on Wau, an Australian base that potentially threatened the Japanese positions at Salamaua and Lae. A race developed between the Japanese moving overland, hampered by the terrain, and the Australians, moving by air, hampered by the weather. By the time the Japanese reached the Wau area after a trek over the mountains, the Australian defenders had been greatly reinforced by air. In the battle that followed, despite achieving tactical surprise by approaching from an unexpected direction, the Japanese attackers were unable to capture Wau.
column4: Die Schlacht von Wai vom 29–31. Jänner 1943 war Teil der Operationen auf Neuguinea. Japanische Truppen überquerten die Solomonensee von Rabaul und landeten trotz alliierter Luftangriffe bei Lae, wonach sie auf dem Landweg nach Wau, einer australischen Basis, vorstießen. Ein Rennen entstand zwischen japanischen Truppen auf dem Landweg und australischen Verstärkungen auf dem Luftweg. Beide Seiten wurden durch das Gelände und Wetter behindert. Als die Japaner Wau erreichten konnten sie die Australier zwar überraschen, jedoch waren diese so stark verstärkt worden, dass ihnen die Eroberung der Basis nicht gelang.

column2: Victorious Battle of Singapore

The Battle of Singapore was fought in the southeast Asian theatre of World War II when the Empire of Japan invaded the Allied stronghold of Singapore. Singapore was the major British military base in South East Asia and nicknamed the 'Gibraltar of the East'. The fighting in Singapore lasted from 8 December 1941 to 15 February 1942. It resulted in the fall of Singapore to the Japanese, and the largest surrender of British-led military personnel in history. About 80,000 British, Australian and Indian troops became prisoners of war, joining 50,000 taken by the Japanese in the Malayan campaign. Britain's Prime Minister Winston Churchill called the ignominious fall of Singapore to the Japanese the 'worst disaster' and 'largest capitulation' in British history.
column4: 'Die Schlacht von Singapur dauerte vom 8. Dezember 1941 bis 15. Februar 1942. Sie resultierte im Fall von Singapur, dem 'Gibraltar des Pazifik', der wichtigsten britischen Basis in dem Gebiet. Es war die größte Kapitulation von british geführten Truppen in der Geschichte. Etwa 80000 Briten, Australier und Inder gingen in Gefangenschaft.'

column2: Victorious Battle of Tarakan

The Battle of Tarakan was the first stage in the Borneo campaign of 1945. It began with an amphibious landing by Australian forces on 1 May, code-named Operation Oboe One. While the battle ended with success for the Allied forces over the Japanese defenders, this victory is generally regarded as having not justified its costs.
column4: Die Schlacht von Tarakan war die erste Stufe in der Operation auf Borneo 1945. Am 1. Mai landeten australische Truppen in der Operation Oboe One und schlugen die Japaner in der Schlacht, jedoch mit hohen Verlusten, von denen man generell sagt dass sie es nicht wert waren.

column2: Victorious Battle in Berlin

The Battle in Berlin dealt with the ever tightening ring around the German capital. The outcome of the Battle in Berlin was decided during the initial phases of the Battle of Berlin that took place outside the city. As the Soviets invested Berlin and the German forces placed to stop them were destroyed or forced back, the city's fate was sealed. Nevertheless, there was much heavy fighting within the city of Berlin as the Red Army fought its way, street by street, through to the centre of the city. On 23 April 1945, the first Soviet ground forces started to penetrate the outer suburbs of Berlin. By 27 April, Berlin was completely cut off from the outside world. The battle in the city continued until 2 May 1945. On that date, the commander of the Berlin Defence Area, General Helmuth Weidling, surrendered to the commander of the Soviet 8th Guards Army, Lieutenant-General Vasily Chuikov. Chuikov was a constituent of Marshal Georgiy Zhukov's 1st Belorussian Front.
column4: Die Schlacht von Berlin am Ende des 2. Weltkrieges war bereits entschieden, bevor die Stadt von russischen Truppen eingeschlossen wurde, als die deutschen Truppen, die die Stadt decken sollten, außerhalb der Stadt zerschlagen wurden. Es gab jedoch in der gesamten Stadt heftige Gefechte bis die Russen am 23. April 1945 in die Vorstädte eindrangen. Am 27. April war Berlin komplett abgeschnitten und die Schlacht ging bis 2. Mai weiter, bis der deutsche General Helmuth Weidling die Kapitulation unterzeichnete.

column2: Victorious Battle of Pegu

The Battle of Pegu took place from 3 March to 7 March 1942. Japanese forces closed in on the British Indian Army who was deployed near Pegu. The 'B' Squadron of the 7th Hussars arrived in the village of Payagyi to find the Japanese already there. A confused battle ensued. Then the order came for the British to move to Hlegu. Hlegu was also in Japanese hands as the British approached. The Japanese had erected a roadblock and they defended it with molotov cocktails. In the end, they were forced to retreat in the face of heavy fire from the tanks. General Alexander had realised that Rangoon was doomed, and his new plan involved a withdrawal to Prome, some 200 miles to the north. The objective, to convince the Japanese that Rangoon would be defended, had been achieved. The British Indian Army moved on to Taukkyan that evening.
column4: Die Schlacht von Pegu fand von 3. bis 7. März 1942 statt als japanische Truppen die britisch-indische Armee bei Pegu angriff. Nachdem britische Panzer eingriffen wurden die Japaner zurückgedrängt. General Alexander war klar dass Rangun nicht zu halten war und zog sich nach Prome in Norden zurück. Das Ziel die Japaner zu überzeugen dass Rangun verteidigt würde war erreicht worden.

column2: Victorious Battle of Tampere

The Battle of Tampere of the Finnish Civil War was fought in Finland in 1918 between Red and White forces. The White forces besieged and captured the main city of the Red Guards, Tampere, taking 10,000 Red prisoners.
column4: Die Schlacht von Tampere im finnischen Bürgerkrieg wurde 1918 zwischen roten und weißen Truppen ausgefochten. Die weißen Truppen belagerten die Stadt und nahmen sie schließlich ein, wobei sie 10000 rote Gefangene machten.

column2: Victorious Battle of Wilno

The Battle of Wilno was one of the major battles during the Soviet invasion of Poland that accompanied the larger German invasion. During the days of 18-19 September, the Soviet forces approached and took over the major city of Wilno. The Polish forces in the area were relatively weak and the Polish commanders, unsure whether to actively oppose the Soviets, did not utilise the full defensive capabilities of the town and nearby fortified areas, although the outcome of the battle could not be any different, given the overwhelming Soviet numerical superiority.
column4: Die Schlacht von Wilno war eines der letzten größeren Gefechte während des russischen Einmarsches in Polen 1939. Während des 18-19. September nahmen sowjetische Truppen die Stadt gegen relativ schwachen polnischen Widerstand ein da die polnischen Kommandeure nicht sicher waren, ob sie den Russen Widerstand entgegensetzen sollten.

column2: Victorious Battle of Palmyra

The Battle of Palmyra was part of the Allied invasion of Syria during the Syria-Lebanon campaign. The Habforce set off on June 21 and surrounded Palmyra. On June 28 they captured the French fort of Seba' Biyar, the small garrison surrendering without a shot fired, and the next day they occupied Sukhna. On the morning of July 1 Sukhna was attacked by the Vichy 2nd Light Desert Company. The Arab Legion occupiers had been reinforced by a squadron from 4th Cavalry Brigade's Household Cavalry Regiment and after a sharp battle, the French retreated and ended up trapped in a box valley before surrendering. Whilst hardly the largest battle of the war, its effect was to cause the 3rd Light Desert Company to lose heart and they surrendered Palmyra on the night of 2 July.
column4: Die Schlacht von Palmyra war Teil der alliierten Invasion von Syrien. Die Habforce umkreiste Palmyra am 21. Juni und nach einigen harten Kämpfen mit der Vichy-Garnison kapitulierte die Stadt schließlich am 2. Juli.

column2: Victorious Battle of Leningrad

The Siege of Leningrad took place from 8 September 1941 to 27 January 1944. It was one of the longest and most destructive sieges in history and the most costly in terms of casualties. It caused the greatest destruction and the largest loss of life ever known in a modern city. Most of the palaces of the Tsars and other historic landmarks located outside the city's defensive perimeter were looted and then destroyed. A number of factories, schools, hospitals and other civil infrastructure were destroyed by air raids and long-range artillery bombardment. The siege resulted in the deaths of up to 1,500,000 soldiers and civilians and the evacuation of 1,400. Civilians in the city suffered from extreme starvation. In January-February of 1942 about 7000 - 10 000 citizens died every day, most of them from hunger.
column4: Die Belagerung von Leningrad dauerte vom 8. September 1941 bis zum 27. Jänner 1944. Sie war eine der längsten und zerstörerischten Belagerungen der Geschichte und die mit den meisten Verlusten. Sie kostete die meiste Zerstörung und die größten Verluste in einer modernen Stadt. Die meisten Zarenpaläste und andere historische Gebäude außerhalb des Verteidigungsringes wurden geplündert und zerstört. Eine Anzahl von Fabriken, Schulen, Spitäler und andere zivile Einrichtungen wurden durch Luftantriffe oder Artillerie vernichtet. Die Belagerung führte zum Tod von bis zu 1,5 Millionen Soldaten und Zivilisten und der Evakuierung von 1,4 Millionen. Zivilisten in der Stadt hungerten. Im Jänner-Februar 1941 starben etwa 7000-10000 Menschen jeden Tag, die meisten davon am Hunger.

column2: Victorious Battle of Iwo Jima

The Battle of Iwo Jima took place from February 19 to March 26, 1945. The United States fought for and captured Iwo Jima from Japan. The Japanese positions on the island were heavily fortified, with vast bunkers, hidden artillery, and 18 km of underground tunnels. The Americans were covered by extensive naval and air support, capable of putting an enormous amount of firepower onto the Japanese positions. Of the more than 18,000 Japanese soldiers present at the beginning of the battle, only 216 were taken prisoner. The rest were killed or were missing and assumed dead. The U.S. invasion was charged with the mission of capturing the two airfields on Iwo Jima. Despite heavy fighting and casualties on both sides, Japanese defeat was assured from the start. The Americans possessed an overwhelming superiority in arms and numbers - this, coupled with the impossibility of Japanese retreat or reinforcement, ensured that there was no plausible scenario in which the United States could have lost the battle.
column4: Die Schlacht von Iwo Jima fand vom 19. Februar bis 26. März 1945 statt. Die USA nahmen die Insel von Japan ein, die mit starken Befestigungen, unterirdischen Gängen von 18km Länge, versteckten Artilleriestellungen und anderen Positionen durchzogen war. Unter starkem Luft- und Seebeschuss überlebten nur 216 der 18000 japanischen Verteidiger. Der Ausgang der Schlacht war aufgrund der übermächtigen Stärke der US Truppen nie in Frage gestellt.

column2: Victorious Battle of Dakar

The Battle of Dakar was an unsuccessful attempt in September 1940 by the Allies to capture the strategic port of Dakar in French West Africa. The Allies decided to send a naval force of an aircraft carrier, two battleships, five cruisers, and ten destroyers to Dakar. Their orders were first to try and negotiate with the Vichy French governor, but, if this was unsuccessful, to take the city by force. The Allied fleet attacked the coastal defences, and the Vichy forces defended them. Overall, the Battle of Dakar did not go well for the Allies. The Vichy forces did not back down. During most of this conflict, bombers of the Vichy French Air Force based in North Africa bombed the British base at Gibraltar. On September 24 about 50 aircraft dropped 150 bombs while on September 25 about 100 aircraft dropped 300 bombs on the harbor and dockyards. Most of the bombs missed. Some damage but few casualties were caused. Finally, the Allies withdrew, leaving Dakar and French West Africa in Vichy hands.
column4: Die Schlacht von Dakar war ein fehlgeschlagener Versuch der Alliierten im September 1940 den strategischen Hafen von Dakar an der westafrikanischen Küste zu erobern. Die Alliierten entsandten einen Träger, 2 Schlachtschiffe, 5 Kreuzer und 10 Zerstörer. Die Vichy-Verteidiger lehnten die Übergabe ab und konnten erfolgreich alle Angriffe abwehren, bis die Alliierten schließlich aufgaben und ihre Flotte zurückzogen.

column2: Victorious Battle of Nanchang

The Battle of Nanchang was the first major conflict to occur following the Chinese defeat at the Battle of Wuhan. Nanchang was a railway center, the major supply line between the 3rd and 9th Military Regions, and site of the airbase threatening Japanese shipping in Yangtze River. By March 27, Nanchang had fallen after being surrounded and put under siege by Japanese forces. During a period lasting until the end of April some Japanese forces were moved to support operations in other areas. This weakening of available Japanese manpower had consequences. On April 21, a surprise attack by the forces of the 3rd and 9th Military Regions allowed for a breakthrough by the 32nd Army Group that allowed a Chinese spearhead to reach the outer area of Nanchang in 5 days. However, under heavy attack from Japanese Aviation and facing a Japanese garrison re-enforced by components of the Navy they were unable to lay an effective siege and retreated on May 9.
column4: Die Schlacht von Nanchang war das erste große Gefecht nach der chinesischen Niederlage in der Schlacht von Wuhan. Nanchang war ein Eisenbahnzentrum sowie ein wichtiger Luftstützpunkt für Angriffe auf die japanische Schifffahrt auf dem Jangtze. Am 27. März war die Stadt gefallen, nachdem sie von japanischen Truppen eingeschlossen und belagert wurde. Bis April wurden einige japanische Truppen verlegt und so konnten die Chinesen durch einen überaschenden Gegenangriff die Stadt ihrerseite einschließen, wurden jedoch von der starken Garnison und der japanischen Luftüberlegenheit zurückgeschlagen und mussten am 9. Mai zurückweichen.

column2: Victorious First Battle of Guam

The First Battle of Guam took place on December 8, 1941 between the Empire of Japan and American forces. On December 8, Japanese aircraft from Saipan attacked Guam. On December 9, a Japanese invasion fleet left Saipan for Guam. On December 10, the 5th Company landed on Dungcas Beach on Agana Bay north of Agana, attacked and quickly captured the Insular Force Guard in Agana. It then advanced on Piti moving toward Sumay and the Marine Barracks. The South Seas Detachment began landing on the north flank ot Tumon Bay on the upper northwest coast and moved towards Agana. The principal engagement took place on Agana's Plaza de Espana when a few Marines and Insuler Force Guardsmen fought with the 5th Company. After token resistance, the Marines surrendered at 05:45 hours. Governor McMillin officially surrendered at 06:00. No further fighting took place, but a few skirmishes took place all over the island before news of the surrender spread and the rest of the island forces surrendered as well.
column4: Die erste Schlacht von Guam fand am 8. Dezember 1941 statt als zuerst japanische Flugzeuge von Saipan die amerikanische Insel angriffen und am 10. landeten die ersten japanischen Truppen in der Aganabucht. Nach geringem Widerstand durch US Marines kapitulierte Governor McMillin offiziell.

column2: Victorious Second Battle of Guam

The Second Battle of Guam took place from July 21 to August 8, 1944 and was the American capture of the Japanese held island of Guam during the Pacific campaign of World War II. On July 21 the Americans landed on both sides of the Orote peninsula on the western side of Guam. Japanese counter-attacks were made throughout the first few days of the battle, mostly at night, using infiltration tactics. Several times they penetrated the American defences and were driven back with heavy loss of men and equipment. The counterattacks around the American beachheads had exhausted the Japanese. At the start of August they were running out of food and ammunition and had only a handful of tanks left. After an engagement at Mount Barrigada from August 2 to August 4, the Japanese line collapsed and the rest of the battle was a pursuit to the north. As in other battles of the Pacific War, the Japanese refused to surrender, and almost all were killed.
column4: Die zweite Schlacht von Guam fand zwischen 21. Juli bis 8. August 1944 statt und beschreibt die amerikanische Landung auf die japanisch besetzte Insel. Nach der Landung der Amerikaner führten die Japaner fast jede Nacht Gegenangriffe durch und durchstießen dabei häufig die US Linien, wurden jedoch jeweils unter hohen Verlusten zurückgeschlagen. Anfang August waren die Japaner fast ohne Nahrung und Munition und hatten nur mehr eine Handvoll Panzer. Wie in den anderen Schlachten im Pazifik lehnten die Japaner aber bis zuletzt jede Kapitulation ab und fast alle starben.

column2: Victorious Battle of Rabaul

The Battle of Rabaul took place in January and February 1942. In January 1942, Rabaul came under attack by large numbers of Japanese carrier based aircraft. On 21 January, eight Wirraways attacked a formation of 109 Japanese aircraft, three RAAF planes were shot down, two crash-landed, and another was damaged. As a result of the intense air attacks, Australian coastal artillery was destroyed and Australian infantry were withdrawn from Rabaul itself. Rabaul became the biggest Japanese base in New Guinea. The Australians tried to restrict its development soon after its capture by a bombing counter attack in March. In December 1943, during the Battle of Cape Gloucester, U.S. Marines landed in western New Britain and consequent Allied operations on New Britain gradually restricted the Japanese force to Rabaul. However, a large number of Japanese personnel remained in Rabaul until the Japanese surrender in August 1945.
column4: Die Schlacht von Rabaul fand im Jänner und Februar 1942 statt, als die Stadt von japanischen Flugzeugen intesiv bombardiert wurde und dadurch die australischen Truppen zum Rückzug gezwungen wurden. Rabaul wurde zur größten japanischen Basis in Neuguinea.US Marines landeten im Westen von Neubrittanien und drängten die Japaner langsam auf Rabaul zurück, jedoch konnten sie die Basis selbst bis zur Kapitulation im August 1945 halten.

column2: Victorious First Battle of Changsha

The First Battle of Changsha took place from September 17, 1939 to October 6, 1939 and was the first attempt by Japan to take the city of Changsha, China. The Japanese launched the attacks on September 17, when their forces in northern Jiangxi attacked westward toward Henan. However, the Japanese stretched too far out westward and were counter-attacked by Chinese forces from the south and the north, forcing them to retreat eastward. On September 23 the Japanese drove the Chinese out of the Sinchiang river area. Heavy fighting continued after the 23rd and the Chinese retreated southward to attract the Japanese while supporting battalions arrived on the east and the west for encirclement maneuver. On September 29 the Japanese reached the outskirts of Changsha. However, they were unable to conquer the city because the Chinese cut off their supply lines. By October 6 the Japanese forces at Changsha were decimated while the remnants retreated northward.
column4: Die erste Schlacht von Changsha fand vom 17. September bis 6. Oktober 1939 statt und war der erste japanische Versuch, die Stadt einzunehmen. Japanische Truppen im Norden von Jiangxi griffen westlich in Richtung Henan an. Jedoch stießen sie zu weit vor und wurden durch einen chinesischen Gegenangriff zurückgeschlacgen. Ein zweiter Angriff erreichte den Rand von Changsha, jedoch wurden die japanischen Nachschublinien abgeschnitten und die Japaner mussten sich nach schweren Verlusten zurückziehen.

column2: Victorious Second Battle of Changsha

The Second Battle of Changsha took place from September 6 to October 8, 1941 and was Japan's second attempt in taking the city of Changsha. The battle started when a small Chinese guerrilla force clashed with the Japanese 6th Division in the mountains southeast of Yueyang on September 6th. On the 17th, the Japanese crossed the Sinchiang River at four points and made rapid advances, crossing the Milo River on the 19th. The main Chinese force avoided confronting the enemy but marched in a parallel fashion flanking the Japanese trail southward. The Chinese and the Japanese army reached the Laotao River regions for an inevitable battle. On September 27th, several hundred Japanese troops in plain clothes reached the north gate of Changsha but were unable to sabotage the city defences, leading to heavy fighting on the 28th. Unable to overcome the defenders, the Japanese began a general retreat back to the Yueyang region on September 30th.
column4: Die zweite Schlacht von Changsha fand vom 6. September bis 8. Oktober 1941 statt und war der zweite japanische Versuch, die Stadt zu erobern. Eine kleine chinesische Guerilliaeinheit startete ein Gefecht mit der japanischen 6. Division in den Bergen südöstlich von Yueyang.  Am 17. September überquerten die Japaner den Fluss Sinchiang an 4 verschiedenen Stellen und stießen rasch vor. Die Hauptkräfte der Chinesen griffen die Japaner nicht direkt an, sondern marschierten an ihren Flanken parallel zum Vormarsch, bis es bei der Stadt Changsha zur Schlacht kam. Die Japaner zogen sich zurück, nachdem sie nicht in der Lage waren, den Verteidigungsring um die Stadt zu durchbrechen.

column2: Victorious Third Battle of Changsha

The Third Battle of Changsha was the third attempt by the Japanese to invade the Chinese province of Hunan. In June 1944 the Japanese deployed 360,000 troops to invade Changsha. On 27th May, 1944, the Japanese 11th Army launched the 1944 general offensive toward Changsha as scheduled. The Japanese flanked the Chinese troops defending Changsha and cut off their possible retreat routes, and placed some secondary divisions in charge of attacking Changsha. The Chinese attempted to use the previous tactic of avoid direct contact by marching in parallel fashion to flank the Japanese, but were unable to encircle the enemy like before and had to retreat. This allowed IJA to rapidly ransack the city of Changsha, breaking the defences of the infantry within the city, as well as neutralizing the Chinese artillery on Yuelu Mountain, and Changsha was quickly lost to the Japanese.
column4: Die dritte Schlacht von Changsha war der dritter japanische Versuch, die chinesische Provinz von Hunan einzunehmen. Im Juni 1944 griffen 360000 Japaner die Stadt Changsha an und am 27. Mai startete die japanische 11. Armee die Offensive. Die chinesischen Verteidiger wurden umgangen und eigekreist. Die Chinesen versuchten, wie in der 2. Schlacht die Japanischen Angriffstruppen zu flankieren, konnten dies jedoch nicht erreichen und mussten sich zurückziehen. Die Japaner nahmen daraufhin die Stadt ein.

column2: Disastrous Battle of the Bzura

We have lost the battle of the Bzura!\n\nThe Battle of the Bzura took place from 9 to 19 September 1939 and was fought between Polish and German forces. The battle, which was one of the last major military actions ever to have been conducted on horseback, took place to the west of Warszawa, near the Bzura River. A Polish breakout attack gained initial success but eventually faltered after a concentrated German counterattack. After many long and hard battles, the Germans outflanked the Polish forces and took all the west Poland.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht an der Bzura verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht an der Bzura wurde vom 9. bis 19. September 1939 ausgefochen und war eine der letzten großen militärischen Operationen, die mit Pferden ausgefochten wurden. Sie fand westlich von Warschau, nahe dem Fluss Bzura statt. Ein polnischer Ausbruchsversuch hatte anfangs Erfolg, jedoch schlug er am Ende durch einen konzentrierten deutschen Gegenangriff fehl. Nach vielen langen und harten Gefechten flankierten die deutschen die polnischen Truppen und brachten ganz Westpolen unter ihre Kontrolle.

column2: Our Losses: $LAND_LOSER_LOSSES$ Enemy Losses: $LAND_WINNER_LOSSES$
This is despicable!
My men have failed me...
Disastrous Battle of Kobryn

We have lost the battle of Kobryn!\n\nThe Battle of Kobryn was fought between September 14 and September 18, 1939, between the German XIX Panzer Corps of General Heinz Guderian and the improvised Polish 'Kobryn' Infantry Division of Colonel Adam Epler. The battle of Kobryn came to an end when general Franciszek Kleeberg, due to the information about the Soviet Invasion of Poland pouring in from the frontline and reports about Red Army forces, decided to send orders to all units of his GO 'Polesie' to immediately stop all combats and withdraw to the south towards the Pinsk Marshes. 60th Infantry Division left Kobryn and marched to the area of Dywin. General Kleeberg also decided to shift the headquarters of his GO 'Polesie' from Pinsk to Lubieszów.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kobryn verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Kobryn wurde zwischen 14. und 18. September 1939 zwischen dem deutschen XIX Panzerkorps unter General Heinz Guderian  und  einer polnischen Infantriedivision unter Colonel Adam Epler ausgefochten. Die Schlacht endete als das polnische Oberkommando aufgrund heranrückender Verbände der Wehrmacht und der Roten Armee den Rückzug in die Sümpfe von Pinsk befahl.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Tomaszow Lubelski

We have lost the battle of Tomaszow Lubelski!\n\nThe Battle of Tomaszow Lubelski took place from 17 September to 26 September 1939 near the town of Tomaszow Lubelski. It was the largest tank battle of the campaign. It resulted in the destruction of the Polish forces, which included one of the largest Polish armored units of that time, the Warszawa Armoured Motorized Brigade. Twice during the battle, Polish units attempted to break through the German positions towards the south. The first attempt ended with the capitulation of the Army Lublin on 20 September. The so-called Northern Front made the next attempt. Only the cavalry group under general Wladyslaw Anders was successful, most of the remaining Polish forces failed to break through and capitulated around 26 September.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von  Tomaszow Lubelski verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Tomaszow Lubelski fand vom 17. bis 26. September 1939 war die größte Panzerschlacht des Feldzuges. Dabei wurden die polnischen Verbände, inklusive des größten polnischen Panzerverbandes, völlig vernichtet. Die Polen versuchten 2 Mal nach Süden durch die deutschen Stellungen durchzubrechen, jedoch konnte nur ein Kavallerieverband dieses Ziel erreichen, der Rest kapitulierte am 26. September.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Kock

We have lost the battle of Kock!\n\nThe Battle of Kock, was the final battle in the Invasion of Poland at the beginning of World War II. It took place between 2–5 October 1939, near the town of Kock, in Poland. The Polish Polesie Independent Operational Group, led by General Franciszek Kleeberg, fought the German 14th Motorised Corps, led by General Gustav von Wiedesheim. The German 14th Motorised Corps was made up of the 29th and 13th Motorised Infantry Divisions and some independent units. One of the last attacks was by the 29thMotorised Division on the 'Podlaska' Cavalry Brigade positions and the rear of the 'Brzoza' Division. This made the Polish formations withdrew to the south of Kryzywda. The Polesie Independent Group surrendered on 6 October at 1000. In his last order General Kleeberg wrote that the reason for his decision to capitulate was that they were surrounded and ammunition and food were depleted.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kock verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Kock war die letzte Schlacht des Feldzuges vom 2–5 Oktober 1939. Die polnische Polesie-Gruppe unter General Franciszek Kleeberg kämpfte gegen das deutsche 14. Motorisierte Korps unter General Gustav von Wiedesheim. Am 6. Oktober um 10 Uhr kapitulierten die Polen, nachdem ihnen der Nachschub ausging.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Stalingrad

We have lost the battle of Stalingrad!\n\nNazi Germany and its allies fought the Soviet Union for control of the city of Stalingrad. The battle took place between 17 July 1942 and 2 February 1943, and is often cited as one of the turning points of the war. The German offensive to capture Stalingrad proceeded rapidly in the late summer of 1942, supported by Luftwaffe bombing which reduced much of the city to rubble. But the Wehrmacht was unable to dislodge the last Soviet defenders, who clung tenaciously to the west bank of the Volga River as the weather turned rainy and cold. In November 1942, the Red Army launched Operation Uranus, a two-pronged attack on the exposed flanks of the German 6th Army in Stalingrad. The weakly held German flanks collapsed and the German 6th Army was cut off and surrounded inside Stalingrad. By early February 1943, German resistance in Stalingrad had ceased, and the surrounded 6th Army had been destroyed.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Stalingrad verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht fand zwischen 17. Juli und 2. Februar 1943 statt und wird oft als Wendepunkt des 2. Weltkrieges bezeichnet. Die deutsche sommeroffensive stieß rasch auf Stalingrad und den Kaukasus vor, jedoch konnte die Wehrmacht die russischen Truppen nicht aus der in Trümmer liegenden Stadt vertreiben. Im November 1942 führte die Rote Armee  Operation Uranus durch, die Gegenoffensive im Norden und Süden, die schnell durch die dort postierten, schlecht ausgerüsteten rumänischen Verbände stieß und die deutsche 6. Armee in Stalingrad einkesselte. Anfang Februar 1943 brach der deutsche Widerstand in der Stadt zusammen und die überlebenden 90000 Mann gingen in Gefangenschaft.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Bialystok–Minsk

We have lost the battle of Bialystok–Minsk!\n\nThe Battle of Bialystok–Minsk was a German strategic operation conducted by the Army Group Centre during penetration of the Soviet border region during the opening stage of Operation Barbarossa lasting from 22 to 29 June 1941. Its goal was encirclement of the Red Army forces around Minsk. Five days after the invasion on 27 June, the pincer of Guderian's 2nd Panzer Army and Hoth's 3rd Panzer Army closed east of Minsk. The Panzer Armies had advanced 321 km into the Soviet Union and almost a third of the distance to Moscow. On 28 June, the 9th and 4th German Armies linked up east of Bialystok, splitting the encircled Soviet forces into two pockets: a smaller Bialystok pocket containing the Soviet 10th Army and a larger Navahrudak pocket containing the 3rd and 13th Armies. On 29 June Minsk, the capital of Belarus, fell to the Wehrmacht. A second Red Army counter-attack by the 20th Mechanized Corps and 4th Airborne Corps failed to breach the encirclement as well, and by 30 June the pocket was completely closed.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Bialystok-Minsk verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Bialystok–Minsk war eine strategische deutsche Operation der Heeresgruppe Mitte zu Beginn der Operation Barbarossa, um die Verbände der Roten Armee um Minsk einzuschließen und zu vernichten. 5 Tage nach der Invasion schloss sich der Ring durch die Panzerspitzen der 2. und 3. Panzergruppen. Andere deutsche Armeen trafen sich bei Bialystok und machten 2 Kessel aus dem großen Ring, die russische 10., 3. und 13. Armeen waren eingekesselt worden.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Raseiniai

We have lost the battle of Raseiniai!\n\nThe Battle of Raseiniai took place from 23 june to 27 June 1941. The tank battle was fought between the elements of the 4th Panzer Army and two Soviet Mechanized Corps in Lithuania, 75 km northwest of Kaunas, in the attempt by the commander of the Northwestern Front to contain and destroy German troops that had crossed the Neman River. The result of the battle was the almost complete destruction of Soviet armoured forces of the Northwestern Front, clearing the way for the continued German offensive towards the crossings of the Daugava River. This was one of the major battles during the initial phases of Operation Barbarossa known in Soviet history as the Border Defensive Battles as part of the larger Baltic Strategic Defensive Operation.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Raseiniai verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Raseiniai fand vom 23. bis 27. Juni 1941 statt. Die Panzerschlacht wurde zwischen der deutschen 4. Panzerarmee und 2 russischen mechanisierten Korps in Litauen ausgetragen. Die sowjetischen Panzerverbände versuchten, den deutschen Vormarsch aufzuhalten und wurden dabei fast vollständig aufgerieben.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Dubna

We have lost the battle of Dubna!\n\nThe Battle of Dubna was a tank battle fought between the Panzer Group 1's IIIrd, XLVIII Army Corps and five Soviet Mechanized Corps in Soviet-occupied Poland between 26 and 30 June 1941 known in Soviet historiography as the Ukrainian Border Defensive Battles. Although the Red Army formations inflicted heavy losses on the German forces, they were outmanoeuvred and suffered large losses in tanks. This was of the most intense armoured engagements in the opening phase of Operation Barbarossa and remained the largest tank battle of World War II until the Battle of Kursk two years later.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Dubna verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Dubna war eine Panzerschlacht zwischen dem III und XLVIII Armeekorps der 1. Panzergruppe und 5 sowjetischen mechanisierten Korps im sowjetisch besetzten Polen zu Beginn der Operation Barbarossa. Obwohl die Deutschen Verluste erlitten, waren die russischen Verluste vor allem an Panzern vernichtend. Das Gefecht blieb bis zur Schlacht bei Kursk 2 Jahre später die größte Panzerschlacht der Ostfront.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Kursk

We have lost the battle of Kursk!

The Battle of Kursk refers to German and Soviet operations on the Eastern Front of World War II in the vicinity of the city of Kursk in July and August 1943. It remains both the largest series of armoured clashes, including the Battle of Prokhorovka and the costliest single day of aerial warfare. It was the last strategic offensive the Germans were able to mount in the east. The resulting decisive Soviet victory gave the Red Army the strategic initiative for the rest of the war.

'Although often thought of as a tank battle, Kursk as a whole arguably demonstrated the triumph of artillery, infantry and engineers over armour. The Soviet plan was to soak up the German assault in a colossal web of defensive positions and only then launch their armoured counter-attack. It was also an important air battle, in which the balance shifted in favour of the Soviets.'
– John Keegan
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kursk verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Kursk fand im Juli und August 1943 an der Ostfront statt. Sie stellt sowohl die Luftschlacht mit den höchsten Verlusten an einem einzigen Tag als auch die größte Panzerschlacht der Geschichte dar. Sie war auch die letzte strategische Offensive der Deutschen an der Ostfront, die den Frontbogen bei Kursk und Orel nicht nicht beseitigen konnten und schwere Panzerverluste erlitten.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Smolensk

We have lost the battle of Smolensk!\n\nThe Battle of Smolensk was a successful encirclement operation by Army Group Centre's 2nd Panzer Army led by Heinz Guderian and the 3rd Panzer Army led by Hermann Hoth of parts of four Soviet Fronts. The Soviet formations were the Western Front commanded by Timoshenko, the Soviet Reserve Front commanded by Zhukov, the Soviet Central Front commanded by Kuznetsov, and Soviet Bryansk Front commanded by Yeremenko. Ultimately the Soviet 16th, 19th and the 20th Armies were encircled just to the south of Smolensk but large parts of the 19th Army managed to escape the pocket. As a result of large parts of Soviet soldiers escaping the net, Hitler called off the operation for encirclement as the premier means of defeating the Soviet Union and concentrated on inflicting severe economic damage to the Soviet Union.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Smolensk verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Smolensk war eine erfolgreiche Umfassungsschlacht der 2. Panzerarmee unter Heinz Guderian under der 3. Panzerarmee unter Hermann Hoth gegen Teile von 4 sowjetischen Fronten unter Timoshenko, Zhukov, Kuznetsov und Yeremenko. Schließlich wurden den russische  16., 19. und 20. Armee südlich von Smolensk eingekreist. Nur kleine Teile der 19. Armee konnten noch entkommen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Uman

We have lost the battle of Uman!\n\nThe Battle of Uman took place during July 15 – August 8, 1941. It was a German encirclement of the 6th and 12th Soviet armies south of the city of Uman during the initial offensive operations of the Army Group South. The battle was part of the Operation Barbarossa on the Eastern Front of World War II. The battles resulted during the Kiev defensive operation by the elements of the Red Army's Southwestern Front defending the Southern Bug bridges and the strategic rail road between Odessa and Smolensk, and the offensives by the elements of the German 1st Panzer Group in Western Ukraine during the later's advance from southern Poland to Crimea. Both armies were later disbanded and escaping troops were incorporated into other units. This was among the large Axis encirclements that were executed against the Red Army in the First period of World War II.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Uman verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Uman fand zwischen 15. Juli und 8. August 1941 statt und war eine deutsche Kesselschlacht gegen die 6. und 12. russische Armee südlich von Uman. Während der Verteidigung von Kiev wurden die beiden Armeen von der deutschen 1. Panzergruppe, die aus Südpolen vorstieß, eingeschlossen. Nur wenige Soldaten konnten entkommen und wurden in andere Einheiten eingegliedert.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Moskva

We have lost the battle of Moskva!\n\nThe Battle of Moskva took place between October 1941 and January 1942. The Soviet defensive effort frustrated Hitler's strategy that considered Moskva, capital of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the largest Soviet city, to be the primary military and political objective for Axis forces in their invasion of the Soviet Union. About 40 well-equipped divisions were stationed in Siberia to keep an eye on Japan. When Stalin realised that Japan wouldn’t attack, the divisions were moved westward and used against the Germans. A desperate Hitler forbade retreat, but the Red Army still pressed back the attacker and one month later, the Wehrmacht was pressed back up to 250 km. The chance of capturing Moscow was gone. For the Russians' part this was a very important victory, especially from a moral point of view - Wehrmacht was not unbeatable after all.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Moskau verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht um Moskau zwischen Oktober 1941 und Jänner 1942 hielt den deutschen Vormarsch auf die russische Hauptstadt auf. Etwa 40 gut ausgerüstete russische Divisionen waren in Sibirien stationiert. Als Stalin überzeugt war, dass Japan nicht angreifen würde, lies er die Truppen nach Westen verlegt um die Deutschen aufzuhalten. Hitler verbot jeden Rückzug, aber die Rote Armee ging zum Gegenangriff über und die Wehrmacht wurde innerhalb eines Monats um 250km zurückgedrängt.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Murmansk

We have lost the battle of Murmansk!\n\nOperation Silver Fox was a joint German–Finnish military operation plan during World War II, though it was mainly operated and engaged by Germans. Its main goal was the capture of the key Soviet port at Murmansk through attacks from Finnish and Norwegian territory. The operation was Unsuccessful and Murmansk continued to operate throughout the war and around a quarter of all Lend Lease material was received through this port and the port of Arkhangelsk. The supplies coming through this port helped the Soviets quickly recover from the disasters of 1941. While the rest of the Soviet lines had collapsed in 1941, the forces of Roman Panin's Northern Front had held, causing casualties of up to 15% on the German attackers. The war in the north dragged on until May 1945. In September 1944 the Finns sued for peace and the Lapland War began. In October 1944 the Red Army conducted the Petsamo-Kirkenes Operation, and achieved a decisive victory over the German forces in the Arctic.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Murmansk verloren!\n\nOperation Silberfuchs war eine finnisch-deutsche Offensive gegen Murmansk aus dem hohen Norden Finnlands und Norwegens. Sie war jedoch nicht erfolgreich und durch Murmansk liefen während des Krieges über ein Viertel aller Lend-Lease Konvois aus England. Als 1944 die Finnen die Seiten wechselten, wurde die Deutschen zurückgeschlagen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Brest-Litovsk

We have lost the battle of Brest-Litovsk!\n\nThe Battle of Brest-Litovsk took place between 14 and 17 September 1939, near the town of Brest-Litovsk. The Polish forces consisting of a small, improvised force which defended the city of Brest and its ancient fortress. The fortress occupied a pivotal position on the Polish lines and its defence could prevent German forces from crossing the Polesia area into Lesser Poland and Galicia to the south. After three days of heavy fights, Polish General Plisowski ordered part of his forces to retreat and regroup to the other side of the river and southwards. The evacuation was completed by early morning, 17 September when the last unit crossing the bridge blew it up to hinder the Germans. An hour later elements of the German 76th infantry regiment entered the fortress - almost unopposed. The German forces managed to take the fortress and then the Red Army took over the fortress from the Wehrmacht. The battle of Brest-Litovsk was over.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Brest-Litovsk verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Brest-Litovsk fand vom 14. bis 17. September 1939 statt. Die polnischen Verteidiger waren eine kleine, zusammengewürfeltet Truppe, die die Deutschen 3 Tage lang aufhielten, bis General Plisowski den Rückzug über den Fluss befahl und die Brücken sprengte. Nach der Einnahmen der Stadt und Festung durch die Deutschen wurde sie an die Rote Armee übergeben.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Mlawa

We have lost the battle of Mlawa!\n\nThe Battle of Mlawa took place from September 1 to September 3, 1939. At noon on September 1, 1939 the 1st Army Corps under General Walter Petzel attacked the Polish line of defence. The German engineers managed to cut through Polish antitank barriers on September 3. The Germans used the local civilians as human shields, which allowed them to capture several bunkers on the left flank of the Polish forces, but were unable to push forwards. On the right flank the attacks were more successful and in the late evening elements of German Wodrig Corps finally broke through the lines of the 79th Infantry Regiment to the rear of the Poles. General Emil Krukowicz-Przedrzymirski ordered retreat, finally abandoning the fortified positions. Although the position was abandoned, the German forces suffered substantial losses and it was not until September 13 they finally managed to reach the Modlin Fortress, located less than 100 kilometres to the south.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Mlawa verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Mlawa fand von 1-3. September 1939 statt als das 1. Korps unter General Walter Petzel die polnischen Verteidigungsstellungen angriff. Deutsche Pioniere konnten einen Weg durch die Panzersperren räumen und die Deutschen setzten Zivilisten als menschliche Schilde ein um mehrere Bunker an der linken Flanke einzunehmen. An der rechten Flanke waren die Angriffe noch erfolgreicher und der polnische General Emil Krukowicz-Przedrzymirski befahl den Rückzug nachdem die ersten deutschen Einheiten durch seine Stellungen gebrochen waren.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Warszawa

We have lost the battle of Warszawa!\n\nThe Battle of Warszawa was fought between the Polish Warszawa Army, garrisoned and entrenched in the capital of Poland, and the German Army. From the very first hours of World War II, Warszawa, the capital of Poland, was a target of an unrestricted aerial bombardment campaign by the German Luftwaffe. Land fighting started on September 8, when the first German armored units reached the Wola area and southwestern suburbs of the city. Despite German radio broadcasts claiming to have captured Warszawa, the attack was stopped and soon afterwards Warszawa was under siege. The siege lasted until September 28, when the Polish garrison under General Walerian Czuma capitulated. The following day approximately 100 000 Polish soldiers left the city and were taken POW. On October 1 the Wehrmacht entered Warszawa, which started a period of German occupation that lasted until the Warszawa Uprising and later until January 17, 1945.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Warschau verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Warschau war der Schlusspunkt der Invasion Polens zu Beginn des 2. Weltkriegs. Die Stadt wurde durch die Luftwaffe während des gesamten Feldzuges schwer bombardiert. Landkämpfe begannan am 8. September, als die ersten deutschen Panzer die Vororte erreichten. Bis zum 28. September wurde die die Stadt belagert, bevor die Garnison schließlich kapitulierte. Etwa 100000 polnische Soldaten gingen in Gefangenschaft. Die Stadt blieb bis zum 17. Jänner 1945 von den Deutschen besetzt.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Den Haag

We have lost the battle of Den Haag!\n\nThe Battle for the Haag took place on May 10, 1940 as part of the Battle of the Netherlands between the Royal Netherlands Army and German paratroopers. German paratroopers dropped in and around The Haag and were given orders to capture Dutch airfields and the city. After taking the city, the plan was to force the Dutch queen Wilhelmina of the Netherlands to surrender and to thus defeat the Dutch within a single day. Although the German troops managed to capture the three airfields, Ypenburg, Ockenburg and Valkenburg, they failed in their primary objective of taking the city of Haag and forcing the Dutch to surrender. Accordingly, the Dutch Army launched a counter-attack several hours later. By the end of May 10 Dutch forces had retaken the captured airfields, but this tactical victory would be short lived as German successes elsewhere insured the total defeat of the Dutch armed forces just four days after crossing the border.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Den Haag verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Den Haag fand am 10. Mai 1940 während der Invasion der Niederlande durch die deutsche Wehrmacht statt. Deutsche Fallschirmjäger landeten bei Den Haag mit dem Befehl, die Stadt und den Flugplatz zu erobern. Nach der Einnahme der Stadt sollte Königin Wilhelmina der Niederlande zur Kapitulation bewegt werden und so die holländische Armee in einem Tag geschlagen werden. Die deutschen Truppen konnten alle Flughäfen einnehmen, jedoch konnten sie die Stadt nicht einnehmen und so auch die Holländer nicht zur Kapitulation zwingen, die einen Gegenangriff durchführten und die Flughäfen noch einem kurz in ihren Besitz brachten bevor deutsche Truppen von der Grenze ankamen.

column2: Disastrous Rotterdam Blitz

We have lost the battle of Rotterdam!\n\nRotterdam was bombarded by the German Air Force on 14 May 1940, during the German invasion of the Netherlands in World War II. The objective was to support the German troops fighting in the city, break Dutch resistance, and force the Dutch to surrender. Germany first attacked the Netherlands on 10 May 1940. Three days later, on the morning of 13 May 1940, the situation in Rotterdam was a stalemate. Dutch garrison forces held the north bank of the Nieuwe Maas river and prevented the Germans from crossing. The Germans sent in the Luftwaffe and a total of 90 bombers from Kampfgeschwader 54 dropped a total of 1,150 x 50 kg and 158 x 250 kg bombs. Nearly 1000 people were killed and 85,000 made homeless. Around 2.6 square kilometres of the city was almost levelled. Schmidt sent a conciliatory message to the Dutch commander General Winkelman, who surrendered shortly afterwards, at Heerjansdam, a village south of Rotterdam.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Rotterdam verloren!\n\nRotterdam wurde am 14. Mai 1940 von der deutschen Luftwaffe während der Invasion der Niederlande bombardiert. Die Ziele waren die holländischen Stellungen am Fluss Nieuwe Maas, die die Deutschen Panzer aufhielten. 1000 Menschen wurden getötet und 85000 obdachlos. Kurze Zeit später kapitulierten die Holländer und übergaben die Stadt an die Deutschen.

column2: Disastrous Battle for Caen

We have lost the battle of Caen!\n\nThe Battle for Caen took place from June to August 1944 and was a battle between Allied and German forces during the Battle of Normandy. On 18 July 942, Allied bombers and fighters attacked five villages on the eastern end of Caen in order to facilitate Operation Goodwood. On the right flank of the operation, Canadian 3rd Infantry Division advanced through the southern part of Caen, finally liberating the city that day. The Germans began a counterattack after midday on 18 July that lasted until 20 July. The operation was an immediate tactical failure for the Second Army however the operation proved to strategic victory at the same time. The operation captured strategically important new ground and tied down four German Corps, which included important armoured divisions, at the moment when the Americans were about to launch Operation Cobra. The battle for Caen was over, as the whole of the city was now in British and Canadian hands.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Caen verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von  Caen fand von Juni- August 1944 zwischen deutschen und alliierten Truppen in der Normandie statt.Am 18. Juli 1942 griffen alliierte Flugzeuge Caen im Rahmen der Operation Goodwood an. Die kanadische 3. Infanteriedivision drang in den südlichen Teil von Caen ein, jedoch starteten die Deutschen noch am gleichen Tag einen Gegenangriff. Die Operation war eine taktische Niederlage, jedoch ein strategischer Sieg für die Alliierten, da es deutsche Truppen, besonders Panzerdivionen, zu einer Zeit band, als die Amerikaner Operation Cobra starteten. Kurze Zeit später wurde Caen komplett von Briten und Kanadiern befreit.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Carentan

We have lost the battle of Carentan!\n\nThe Battle of Carentan took place between June 10 and 14, 1944. The defending German force attempted to hold the city Carentan long enough to allow reinforcements en route from the south to arrive, prevent or delay the merging of the lodgements, and keep the U.S First Army from launching an attack towards Lessay-Périers that would cut off the Cotentin Peninsula. The attacking 101st Airborne Division, landed by parachute on June 6 as part of the American airborne landings in Normandy, was ordered to seize Carentan. In the ensuing battle, the 101st forced passage across the causeway into Carentan on June 10 and June 11. A lack of ammunition forced the German forces to withdraw on June 12. The 17th SS PzG Division counter-attacked the 101st Airborne on June 13. Initially successful, its attack was thrown back by Combat Command A of the U.S. 2nd Armored Division.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Carentan verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Carentan fand zwischen 10. und 14. Juni 1944 statt. Die Deutsche versuchten, die Stadt gegen die 101. Luftlandedivision zu halten, um das Abschneiden der Halbinsel Carentin zu vermeiden. Die Deutschen mussten sich aus Munitionsmangel nach 2 Tagen zurückziehen, jedoch führte die 17. SS-Panzergrenadierdivision am 13. Juni einen Gegenangriff auf die Stadt, der zuerst Erfolg hatte, dann jedoch von amerikanischen Bombern und der 2. Panzerdivision abgewiesen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Cherbourg

We have lost the battle of Cherbourg!\n\nThe Battle of Cherbourg was part of the Battle of Normandy during World War II. It was fought immediately after the successful Allied landings on June 6, 1944. American troops isolated and then captured the fortified port in a hard-fought campaign of three weeks. The Corps commander, Major General J. Lawton Collins, launched a general assault on June 22. Resistance was stiff at first, but the Americans slowly cleared the Germans from their bunkers and concrete pillboxes. On June 26, the 79th Division captured Fort du Roule, which dominated the city and its defences. The harbor fortifications and the Arsenal surrendered a few days later, after a token resistance. Some German troops cut off outside the defences held out until July 1. The Germans had sustained a major defeat, as a result of a rapid Allied build-up on their western flank and Hitler's rigid orders.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Cherbourg verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Cherbourg war Teil der Landung in der Normandie. US Truppen schnitten die Hafenstadt ab und nahmen sie nach 3 Wochen harter Kämpfe ein. Ihr Korpskommandeur Major General J. Lawton Collins, startete am 22. Juni den Generalangriff gegen starken Widerstand. Die letzten deutschen Truppen in der Stadt kapitulierten am 1. Juli.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Dodecanese

We have lost the battle of Dodecanese!\n\nThe Dodecanese Campaign of World War II was an attempt by Allied forces, mostly British, to capture the Italian-held Dodecanese islands in the Aegean Sea following the surrender of Italy in September 1943, and use them as bases against the German-controlled Balkans. The Allied effort failed, with the whole of the Dodecanese falling to the Germans within two months, and the Allies suffering heavy losses in men and ships. The operations in the Dodecanese, lasting from 8 September to 22 November 1943, resulted in one of the last German victories in the war.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht auf den Dodekanes verloren!\n\nDer Feldzug auf den Dodekanes war der Versuch der Alliierten, die italienischen Inseln nach der italienischen Kapitulation vor den Deutschen zu besetzen. Im September 1943 landeten sie auf mehreren Inseln, wurden jedoch durch deutsche Luftangriffe und Luftlandungen zurückgeschlagen und erlitten hohe Verluste in Soldaten und Schiffen. Bis Ende 1943 hatten die Deutschen einen ihrere letzten großen Siege errungen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Groningen

We have lost the battle of Groningen!\n\nThe Battle of Groningen took place from April 13 to April 16, 1945, in the city of Groningen, between a mixture of German soldiers, Dutch and Belgian SS troops and the entire 2nd Canadian Infantry Division. German soldiers in the city were determined to keep enemy forces from German soil while their Dutch SS colleagues had reason to fear for their lives if forced to surrender. The fight in the central market square, Grote markt, was the fiercest part of the battle. There were several German machine guns in the buildings north of the square. The buildings had to be destroyed by tanks. The German commander surrendered on 16 April once it was clear further resistance was useless. Over 5,200 Germans surrendered and the remaining Germans fled northeast, and the 2nd Division again met them in battles such as the Battle of Gruppenbuhren near Delmenhorst.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Groningen verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Groningen fand zwischen 13. und 16.
