April 1945 in der holländischen Stadt statt zwischen einer Truppe auf deutschen sowie holländischen und belgischen SS-Soldaten und der kanadischen 2. Infanteriedivision. Nach schweren Häuserkämpfen kapitulierte der deutsche Kommandeur am 16. April, nachdem weiterer Widerstand aussichtslos geworden war. Über 5200 Deutscher wurden gefangen und die Reste zogen sich nach Norden zurück.

column2: Disastrous Battle of San Marino

The Battle of San Marino took place from 17 September to 20 September 1944. German Army forces occupied the neutral Republic of San Marino and were attacked by Allied forces. A strong Allied force aimed to pass through Rimini, east of San Marino, and break out onto the plains north of the city. In response to the Allied movements, the Germans sent a small force into San Marino to guard their lines of communication. After a few days, the main thrust of the offensive was halted south of Rimini by strong resistance and severe weather, and the British and Indian flanking forces began to push westwards, taking the frontline towards San Marino. On 17 September the 4th Indian Division attacked forces of the 278 Infanterie-Division, which held two hills just across the Sanmarinese border. After heavy fighting to gain control of the hills, the situation stabilised on the 19th, and Allied forces began to push into the city of San Marino itself. The city was captured by the afternoon of 20 September.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von San Marino verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von San Marino fand vom 17. bis 20. September 1944 in der neutralen Republik San Marino statt, die von den deutschen Truppen besetzt wurde um ihre Nachschublinien zu schützen und dann von den Alliierten angegriffen wurden. Die 4. indische Division griff die deutschen Truppen an und nahm die Stadt selbst am 20. September ein.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Maastricht

We have lost the battle of Maastricht!\n\nThe Battle of Maastricht took place May 10, 1940. The Dutch forces defended several important locations around Maastricht, the sluice complex north of Maastricht at Borgharen, several bridges and outer-defences of the city. The German forces tried to move into the city and take over the bridges leading over the Maas River. But the Dutch managed to destroy all of the bridges over the Maas River and then the only tasked that remained was to hold off the Germans a long as they could. The German losses were high. However, soon after, three more German Armored Cars approached. The situation for the light Dutch infantry had become critical. Many defenders were killed or wounded by the German fire. The headquarters were contacted and the Dutch resistance at Maastricht was ordered to cease. Lieutenant-Colonel Govers went to the Wilhelminabrug under the banner of truce. Soon contact was established. A few hours later, all Dutch troops in Maastricht and surroundings capitulated.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Maastricht verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Maastricht fand am 10. Mai 1940 statt. Die Holländer verteidigten die Brücken und Verteidigungsstellungen der Stadt während die Deutschen den Fluss Maas überschreiten wollten. Deutsche Verluste waren hoch, jedoch erhielten sie laufend Verstärkung und Lieutenant-Colonel Govers, der holländische Kommandeur, und kapitulierte vor den Deutschen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Arnhem

We have lost the battle of Arnhem!\n\nThe Battle of Arnhem took place from 17 to 26 September 1944. After sweeping through France and Belgium in the summer of 1944, the Allies were poised to enter the Netherlands. The Allies launched Operation Market Garden on 17 September. Paratroopers were dropped in the Netherlands to secure key bridges and towns along the Allied axis of advance. The British 1st Airborne Division landed at Arnhem to secure bridges across the Lower Rhine but no reinforcements managed to get to them. The small British force at the bridge was overwhelmed after four days and the rest of the division became trapped in a small pocket. After nine days of fighting, the shattered remains of the airborne forces were withdrawn in Operation Berlin. With no secure bridges the Allies were unable to cross the Rhine and the frontline stabilized south of Arnhem. The 1st Airborne Division had lost nearly three quarters of its strength and did not see combat again.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Arnheim verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Arnhem fand vom 17. bis 26. September 1944 statt, nachdem die Alliierten durch Frankreich und Belgien vorgedrungen waren. Operation Market Garden war eine großangelegte Luftlandeoffensive der Alliierten, um Brücken auf dem weiteren Vormarschweg zu gewinnen. Die Operation verlief schlecht für die Alliierten, da die Deutschen schnell reagierten, die Fallschirmjäger rasch isolierten und vor allem die 1. britische Luftlandedivision fast vollständig aufrieben. Sie verlore mehr als 2 Drittel ihrer Soldaten und wurde im Krieg nicht mehr eingesetzt.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Metz

We have lost the battle of Metz!\n\nThe Battle of Metz was a land battle fought between the allied forces and the German forces during World War II. It took place at the city of Metz following the Normandy landings. The attack on the city by the United States Third Army faced heavy resistance from the defending German forces, and resulted in heavy casualties for both sides. The battle lasted for several weeks and WE forces captured the heavily fortified city of Metz before the end of November 1944. The battle ended in victory for the allies following the surrender of the remaining German forces.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Metz verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Metz folgte auf die alliierte Landung in der Normandie, als die 3. US Armee auf starken Widerstand der Deutschen stieß. Die Verluste auf beiden Seiten waren hoch, und die Stadt fiel nicht vor Ende November 1944.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Monte Castello

We have lost the battle of Monte Castello!\n\nThe Battle of Monte Castello was fought in Italy from 25 November 1944 to 22 February 1945 and involved the Brazilian Expeditionary Force and the German Army. On November 24 the Brazilians launched a three-day attack that was a compete failure, costing them 34 dead and 153 wounded. On the 29th, the Brazilians again attacked, this time with three battalions, together with support from artillery and tanks, again Unsuccessfully. The Allies then pounded the German positions with artillery fire and air attacks for six days. On 12 December, the Brazilians launched a surprise attack, but the US artillery compromised the attack, which soon bogged down. In February, the newly arrived US 10th Mountain Division, supported by the Brazilian artillery and the Brazilian Expeditionary Force's 1st Fighter squadron, captured the outlying German defences on Monte Castello. On 21 February the Brazilians again attacked, this time successfully.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Monte Castello verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Monte Castello wurde in Italien vom 25. November 1944 bis 22. Februar 1945 statt. Darin standen den Deutschen Soldaten der brasilianischen Expeditionsarmee gegenüber, die einen dreitägigen Angriff führten, der jedoch ein totaler Fehlschlag war. Der Angriff wurde mit Panzerunterstützung widerholt, hatte jedoch wieder keinen Erfolg, und die Alliierten führten starke Luft- und Artilleriebombardements auf die deutschen Stellungen durch. Am 12. Dezember führten die Brasilianer einen Überraschungsangriff, der jedoch noch einmal abgewiesen wurde, bis endlich mit Unterstützung der neu eingetroffenen 10. US Gebirgsdivision ein Angriff am 21. Februar durch die deutschen Stellungen brechen konnte.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Rovaniemi

We have lost the battle of Rovaniemi!\n\nThe Battle of Rovaniemi was an event during the 1944 Lapland War. The actual fighting between the Finnish Armoured Division and the troops of the German Twentieth Mountain Army took place to the south of the town of Rovaniemi. When the Continuation War between Finland and the Soviet Union started in 1941, the Finnish government allowed German troops from the German 20th Mountain Army in Norway to be stationed in Lapland to help defend the long border. When the Finns signed a separate peace with the Soviet Union, relations soured between them and the Germans. The Germans had some 200,000 troops in Finland and they were still at war with the Russians. The operation to level Rovaniemi started on October 10th 1944. The mostly wooden town burned for 6 days, with only 13 buildings left standing. There were no civilian casualties as the Finns had already evacuated the town in September.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Rovaniemi verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Rovaniemi fand während des Laplandkrieges 1944 zwischen der finnischen Panzerdivision und der deutschen 12. Gebirgsarmee statt. Nach der finnischen Kaptitulation mussten sie gegen ihre früheren Verbündeten kämpfen, die etwa 200000 Mann in Finnland stationiert hatten. Die Stadt wurde bei den Kämpfen komplett zerstört, jedoch waren bereits vorher alle Zivilisten evakuiert worden.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Lille

We have lost the battle of Lille!\n\nThe battle of Lille was a Second World War battle fought during the Battle of France. It took place from 28 May 1940 through 31 May 1940 in the surroundings of the city of Lille, France during the Battle of France. It involved approximately 40,000 French of the French First Army who fought against seven German divisions, including three armoured divisions. As a consequence of the continued French resistance, a number of Allied formations managed to escape to Dunkirk,. During the battle the French counterattacked, even capturing the German General, Kühne, commander of the German 251st infantry division.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Lille verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Lille fand vom 28.-31. Mai 1940 während der Schlacht um Frankreich statt. Etwa 40000 Soldaten der französischen 1. Armee kämpften gegen 7 deutschen Divisionen, inklusive 3 Panzerdivisionen. Durch den starken Widerstand der Franzosen konnten mehrere alliierte Einheiten nach Dünkirchen entkommen. Die Franzosen konnten bei einem Gegenangriff sogar den deutschen General Kühne, den Kommandeur der 251. Infanteriedivision, gefangennehmen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Ulm

We have lost the battle of Ulm!\n\nThe city of Ulm was heavily bombed during World War II. The heaviest air raid was on 17 December 1944, which killed and injuring hundreds and left 25,000 people homeless. But the Ulm Münster still towered above the ruins, as it was left intact by Allied bombers who utilized it as a navigational landmark. This was the British Royal Air Force Bomber Command's first and only raid on Ulm. Two large truck factories, Magirus-Deutz and Kässbohrer were the primary targets. There were several other important industries and some Wehrmacht barracks and depots. A total of 1,449 tons of bombs were dropped during the 25-minute raid, starting in the city center and then creeping back to the west, across the industrial and railway areas and out into the country. The Gallwitz Barracks and several military hospitals were among 14 establishments destroyed.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Ulm verloren!\n\nDie Stadt Ulm wurde am 17. Dezember 1944 vom schwersten Luftangriff getroffen, als britische Bomber 2 LKW-Fabriken sowie mehrere andere Industrieziele in der Stadt bombardierten, tausende Menschen töteten und 25000 Obdachlose zurückließen. 1449 Tonnen Bomben wurden abgeworfen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Aachen

We have lost the battle of Aachen!\n\nThe Battle of Aachen took place from 2 to 21 October 1944. By September 1944, the Wehrmacht had been pushed into Germany proper, after being defeated in France by the Western Allies. During the month of September the first fighting sprung up around Aachen and the city's commander offered to surrender it to the advancing Americans. However, the SS discovered his letter of surrender during a raid in Aachen while the civilians were evacuating. Adolf Hitler ordered his immediate arrest and replaced him and his division with Gerhard Wilck's 246th Volksgrenadier Division. The United States' First Army would have to take the city by force. The 30th Infantry Division's offensive began on 2 October and was immediately bogged down by the German defenses. Despite fierce German resistance, German General Wilck surrendered Aachen to American troops on 21 October, ending the battle.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Aachen verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Aachen fand vom 2. bis 21. Oktober 1944 statt. Nach der Niederlage in Frankreich wurde die Wehrmacht auf die deutsche Grenze zurückgedrängt und im September kam es zu ersten Kämpfen im Raum Aachen,  der Stadtkommandant wollte die Stadt übergeben, der Befehl wurde jedoch von der SS gefunden und Hitler ließ ihn sofort exekutieren. Die US Armee griff die Stadt daraufhin an und wurde sofort in schweren Häuserkämpfen aufgehalten. Nach 3 Wochen schwerer Kämpfe kapitulierte der deutsche General Wilck schließlich in der Stadt, die als erste große deutsche Stadt fiel.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Monte Cassino

We have lost the battle of Monte Cassino!\n\nThe Battle of Monte Cassino was a costly series of four battles during World War II, fought by the Allies with the intention of breaking through the Winter Line and seizing Rome. In the beginning of 1944, the western half of the Winter Line was being anchored by Germans holding the Rapido, Liri and Garigliano valleys and certain surrounding peaks and ridges, together known as the Gustav Line. The Germans had not occupied the historic hilltop abbey of Monte Cassino. On 15 February, the monastery was destroyed by 1,400 tons of bombs dropped by American bombers. Two days after the bombing, German paratroopers took up positions in the ruins. The destruction caused by the bombing and the resulting jagged wasteland of rubble gave troops improved protection from air and artillery attack making it a more viable defensive position. From 17 January to 18 May, the Gustav defences were assaulted four times by Allied troops.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Montte Cassino verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Monte Cassino war eine Serie von 4 Gefechten in denen die Alliierten unter hohen Verlusten durch die Winterlinie auf Rom durchbrachen. Das alte Kloster von Monta Cassino wurde vom 1400 Tonnen Bomben von alliierten Flugzeugen zerstört und und anschließend von deutschen Fallschirmjägern besetzt. Die Trümmer lieferten weit besseren Schutz als das Kloster und so konnten die Deutschen 4 Angriffe mit schweren Verlusten für die Alliierten zurückschlagen, bis die Linien aufgegeben wurde.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Nancy

We have lost the battle of Nancy!\n\nThe Battle of Nancy in September 1944 was a ten-day battle on the Western Front of World War II in which the U.S. Third Army defeated German forces defending the approaches to Nancy and crossings over the Moselle River to the north and south of the city. The battle resulted in U.S. forces fighting their way across the Moselle and liberating Nancy.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Nancy verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Nancy im September 1944 war eine zehntägige Schlacht an der Westfront, als die 3. US Armee die deutschen Truppen in der Umgebung von Nancy zurückdrängten und den Übergang über die Mosel erzwangen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Bastogne

We have lost the battle of Bastogne!\n\nThe siege of Bastogne was an engagement between American and German forces at the Belgian town of Bastogne, as part of the larger Battle of the Bulge. The goal of the German offensive was the harbor at Antwerp. In order to reach it before the Allies could regroup and bring their superior air power to bear, German mechanized forces had to seize the roadways through eastern Belgium. Because all seven main roads in the Ardennes mountain range converged on the small town of Bastogne, control of its crossroads was vital to the German attack. The siege lasted from December 20 to December 27 when the besieged American forces were relieved by elements of General Patton's Third Army.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Bastogne verloren!\n\nDie Belagerung von Bastogne dauerte vom 20. Dezember bis zum 27. Dezember und wurde in der belgischen Stadt zwischen deutschen und amerikanischen Truppen ausgefochten. Das Ziel der Deutschen ware es, den Hafen von Antwerpen zu erobern bevor sich die Alliierten sammeln und ihre übermächtige Luftwaffe einsetzen konnten. Deutsche Panzerspitzen hatten die Straßen durch Ostbelgien erobert. Weil alle 7 Haupstraßen in den Ardennen bei Bastogne zusammentrafen, war die Stadt immens wichtig für den deutschen Plan. Die Belagerung ging weiter bis sie von Elementen der 3. Armee unter Patton gebrochen wurde.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Debrecen

We have lost the battle of Debrecen!\n\nThe Battle of Debrecen, called by the Red Army the Debrecen Offensive Operation, took place between 6 October - 28 October 1944 and was conducted by the 2nd Ukrainian Front on the Eastern Front of World War II. It was opposed by Army Group South Ukraine's General Maximilian Fretter-Pico's Sixth Army and allied Hungarian VII Army Corps units which were forced to retreat some 160 kilometers, while opposing Marshal Rodion Malinovsky's 2nd Ukrainian Front which had Debrecen, Hungary as its strategic objective.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Debrecen verloren!\n\nThe Battle of Debrecen, called by the Red Army the Debrecen Offensive Operation, took place between 6 October - 28 October 1944 and was conducted by the 2nd Ukrainian Front on the Eastern Front of World War II. It was opposed by Army Group South Ukraine's General Maximilian Fretter-Pico's Sixth Army and allied Hungarian VII Army Corps units which were forced to retreat some 160 kilometers, while opposing Marshal Rodion Malinovsky's 2nd Ukrainian Front which had Debrecen, Hungary as its strategic objective.

column2: Disastrous First Battle of El Alamain
column4: Verlorene erste Schlacht von El Alamein

column2: We have lost the first battle of El Alamain!\n\nThe First Battle of El Alamein 1–27 July 1942 was a battle of the Western Desert Campaign of the Second World War, fought between Axis forces commanded by Erwin Rommel, and Allied forces commanded by Claude Auchinleck. The battle halted the second advance by the Axis forces into Egypt, El Alamein being only 66 miles from Alexandria.
column4: Wir haben die erste Schlacht von El Alamein verloren!\n\nDie erste Schlacht von El Alamein vom 1–27. Juli 1942 in der westlichen Wüste von Ägypten wurde vom deutschen Afrikakorps unter Erwin Rommel und den alliierten unter Claude Auchinleck statt. Die Schlacht stoppte den zweiten Vorstoß der Achsentruppen nach Ägypten, nur 66 Meilen vor Alexandria.

column2: Disastrous Second Battle of El Alamein
column4: Verlorene zweite Schlacht von El Alamein

column2: We have lost the second battle of El Alamain!\n\nThe Second Battle of El Alamein marked a major turning point in the Western Desert Campaign of the Second World War. The battle lasted from 23 October to 5 November 1942. The First Battle of El Alamein had stalled the Axis advance. Thereafter, Lieutenant-General Bernard Montgomery took command of the British Eighth Army from General Claude Auchinleck in August 1942. The Allied victory turned the tide in the North African Campaign. It ended Axis hopes of occupying Egypt, taking control of the Suez Canal, and gaining access to the Middle Eastern oil fields.
column4: Wir haben die zweite Schlacht von El Alamein verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von El Alamein war der Wendepunkt im Krieg in Afrika. Die schlacht dauerte vom 23. Oktober bis 5. November 1942. Nachdem in der ersten Schlacht die Achsentruppen gestoppt wurden, übernahm Lieutenant-General Bernard Montgomery die 8. britische Armee und führte einen erfolgreichen Gegenangriff, der zum langen Rückzug der Achse nach Tunesien führte.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Malaya

We have lost the battle of Malaya!\n\nThe Battle of Malaya was a campaign fought by Allied and Japanese forces in Malaya, from December 8, 1941 to January 31, 1942 during the Second World War. The campaign was dominated by land battles between British Commonwealth army units, and the Imperial Japanese Army. For the British, Indian, Australian and Malayan forces defending the colony, the campaign was a disaster. The battle is notable for the Japanese use of bicycle infantry, which allowed troops to carry more equipment and swiftly move through thick jungle terrain. Royal Engineers, equipped with demolition charges, destroyed over a hundred bridges during the retreat, which did little to delay the Japanese. By the time the Japanese had captured Singapore, they had suffered 9,600 casualties.

column2: Disastrous Second Battle of Kharkov

We have lost the second battle of Kharkov!\n\nThe Second Battle of Kharkov took place from May 12 to May 28, 1942 and was an Axis counteroffensive against the Red Army Izium bridgehead offensive. After initial promising signs, the offensive was stopped by German counterattacks. column2: Disastrous Battle of Odessa

We have lost the battle of Odessa!\n\nThe Siege of Odessa was part of the Soviet-German War in 1941. Romanian forces and elements of the German Army’s 11th Army primarily conducted the siege. column2: Disastrous Battle of Bautzen

We have lost the battle of Bautzen!\n\nThe Battle of Bautzen, fought on the extreme southern flank of the Spremberg–Torgau Offensive, saw days of pitched street fighting between forces of the 2nd Polish Army, the Red Army's 52nd Army and remnants of the German 4th Panzer and 17th Armies, and was the last successful German armoured counteroffensive of the Second World War. column2: Disastrous Battle of Halbe

We have lost the battle of Halbe!\n\nThe Battle of Halbe took place from April 24 to May 1, 1945 and was a battle in which the Red Army destroyed the German Ninth Army. column2: Disastrous Battle of Narva

In ensuing fierce Battle of Tannenberg Line, the German army group held the line. column2: Disastrous Battle of Ilomantsi

Moscow could now only decide that the Finns had plenty of fight left in them, and that they would never accept an unconditional surrender. column2: Disastrous Battle of Bologna

column2: Disastrous Battle of Ortona

column2: Disastrous Battle of Rimini

We have lost the battle of Rimini!\n\nThe Battle of Rimini is a name used to describe Operation Olive, the main Allied offensive on the Gothic Line in August and September 1944 during the Italian Campaign in the Second World War. column2: Disastrous Battle of Breslau

We have lost the battle of Breslau!\n\nThe Siege of Breslau took place from 13 February to 6 May 1945 and was a three month long Soviet siege of the city of Breslau in Lower Silesia, Germany. The Siege of Breslau consisted of destructive house-to-house street fighting. The city was bombarded to ruin by artillery of the Soviet 6th Army, as well as the Soviet 2nd Air Army and the Soviet 18th Air Army. column2: Disastrous Battle of Borodino

We have lost the battle of Borodino!\n\nThe Battle at Borodino Field was a part of the Battle of Moskva, on the Eastern Front of World War II. column2: Disastrous Battle of Budapest

column2: Disastrous Battle of Kerch

We have lost the battle of Kerch!\n\nThe Battle of the Kerch Peninsula took place from May 8, 1942 to May 18, 1942 and was a World War II offensive by German and Romanian armies against the Soviet Crimean Front forces defending the Kerch Peninsula, in the eastern part of the Crimea. Many of them died underground, including those who died of numerous poison gas attacks during counterattacks by the German Army.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kerch verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht um die Halbinsel Kerch von 8. bis 18. Mai war eine deutsch-rumänische Offensive gegen die sowjetische Krimfront. column2: Disastrous Battle of Kolberg

We have lost the battle of Kolberg!\n\nThe Battle of Kolberg was the taking of the city of Kolberg in Pomerania by the Soviet Army and its Polish allies from Nazi German forces during the World War II East Pomeranian Offensive. column2: Disastrous Battle for Velikie Luki

We have lost the battle of Velikie Luki!\n\nThe Velikiye Luki offensive operation was executed by the forces of the Red Army's Kalinin Front against the Wehrmacht’s 3rd Panzer Army during the Winter Campaign of 1942-1943 with the objective of liberating the Russian city of Velikie Luki as part of the northern pincer of the Rzhev-Sychevka Strategic Offensive Operation. column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Velikie Luki verloren!\n\nDie Offensive bei Velikiye Luki wurde von Truppen der Roten Armee gegen die deutsche 3. Panzerarmee im Winter von 1942-43. column2: Disastrous Battle of Voronez

We have lost the battle of Voronez!\n\nThe Battle of Voronez took place from December 1941 to 6 July 1942. The city was defended by the troops of the 40th Army as part of the Valuiki-Rossosh Defensive Operation. The German assault was conducted by the element of the 4th Panzer Army's forces of the Army Group South, commanded by General Hermann Hoth. Hoth was under strict instructions not to get bogged down in street-to-street fighting. The armoured units of the 4th Panzer Army partly captured Voronez on 6 July by occupying the western river-bank suburbs, however German troops were subjected to a Red Army counter-attack. The 4th Panzer Army was to be followed by the Sixth Army, and when Voronez was occupied the former was to wheel south-eastward and move down the right bank of the Don towards Stalingrad as part of Operation Blau. It took two days for infantry divisions from the Army Group South to reach Voronez to hold the line and free the Panzer troops.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Voronez verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Voronez fand von Dezember 1941 bis 6. Juli 1942 statt. Die Stadt wurde von Truppen der russischen 40. Armee verteidigt gegen Elemente der deutschen 4. Panzerarmee, die von General Hermann Hoth geführt wurde. Panzerarmee folgte, konnte Voronez schließlich sichern und weiter gegen Stalingrad vorstoßen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Calais

We have lost the battle of Calais!\n\nThe Battle of Calais took place from 22 May to 26 May 1940. When the German offensive was launched in May 1940, Calais was subjected to increasingly heavy bombing, which caused disruption to military movements. On 20 May, the Germans seized Abbeville on the River Somme, capturing the last bridges over the river before the sea, and effectively isolating the BEF in Flanders and Picardy, cut off from its logistic bases. On the morning of 26 May, Calais Nord and the Citadel were pounded by artillery, and by 200 German bombers. About mid-afternoon, the Germans finally crossed the bridges over the canal and advanced into Calais Nord. On the other side of the harbour, they captured the Gare Maritime. The citadel was surrounded.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Calais verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Calais fand vom 22. bis 26. column2: Disastrous Battle of Gazala

We have lost the battle of Gazala!\n\nThe Battle of Gazala was an important battle of the Second World War Western Desert Campaign, fought around the port of Tobruk in Libya from May 26 to June 21, 1942. The combatants on the Axis side were the Panzer Army Afrika, consisting of German and Italian units and commanded by the 'Desert Fox' Colonel-General Erwin Rommel, the Allied forces were the Eighth Army, commanded by Major General Neil Ritchie under the close supervision of the Commander-in-Chief Middle East, General Sir Claude Auchinleck. The battle ended in a resounding victory for the Axis. However, devoid of effective armoured forces in subsequent battles, Rommel was unable to pursue and decisively defeat the Eighth Army in Egypt.

Armee unter Major General Neil Ritchie und General Sir Claude Auchinleck gegenüber. Der Ausgang der Schlacht war ein Erfolg der Achse, die jedoch dabei die meisten ihrer Panzer verloren und daher die Briten nicht verfolgen konnten.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Kassel

We have lost the battle of Kassel!\n\nThe Battle of Kassel was a four-day struggle between the U.S. Army and the German Army in April 1945 for Kassel, a medium-sized city northeast of Frankfurt am Main. The battle resulted as the U.S. Third Army pushed northeast from the region of Frankfurt and Mainz. The battle opened on April 1, 1945 and ended with an American victory three days later. Opposing the Third Army's 80th Infantry Division were an infantry replacement battalion, some heavy tanks, and anti-aircraft guns. Although the Germans gave battle at Kassel, their army was on the brink of collapse as the Western Allies and the Red Army made deep inroads into Germany. The defence of Kassel did not materially impede the Allied advance, and, one month after the battle ended, Germany was forced to capitulate.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kassel verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Kassel war ein viertägiges Gefecht zwischen der US Army und der deutschen Wehrmacht im April 1945. Die 3. US Army griff am 1. April 1945 die Stadt an, die von einem Infanterie-Ersatzbatalion, einigen schweren Panzern und Flak verteidigt wurde gegen die 80. US Infanteriedivision. Die Schlacht fand kurz vor dem Ende des Krieges statt und beeinflusste den Kriegsverlauf in keiner Weise.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Tornio

We have lost the battle of Tornio!\n\nThe Battle of Tornio took place from October 1 to October 8, 1944 and was the first major engagement between Nazi Germany and Finland in the Lapland War. The Finnish Infantry Regiment 11 landed unopposed at Röyttä harbour and took the town of Tornio the same day. The German troops in town were surrounded in a few pockets until they surrendered. Further landings in Tornio the next day came under attack of Stuka bombers of Luftwaffe, but was completed successfully despite casualties of 60 men. German counter attacks were repulsed with the aid of a battery of field artillery that was part of the second landing and fire support from Finnish gunboats. Due to lack of roads, the supplies to the troops around Kemi would have to be routed through Rovaniemi. This forced the Germans withdraw their units from Kemi. By October 8 the whole Kemi-Tornio area had been cleared.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Tornio verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Tornio fand vom 1. bis 8. Oktober 1944 statt und war das erste große Gefecht zwischen deutschen und finnischen Truppen im Lapplandkrieg. Das finnische 11. Infanterieregiment landete nahe der Stadt und konnten die Deutschen Truppen einschließen und vernichten. Die Luftwaffe bombardierte die weiteren Landungen, die dennoch mit dem Verlust von 60 Mann durchgeführt wurden. Deutsche Gegenangriffe wurden abgewiesen und bis zum 8. Oktober war das Gebiet von Kemi-Tornio gesichtert.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Malta

We have lost the battle of Malta!\n\nThe Siege of Malta was a military campaign in the Mediterranean Theatre of World War II and took place from 1940 to 1942. The fight for the control of the strategically important island of Malta pitted the air forces and navies of Fascist Italy and Nazi Germany against the Royal Air Force and the Royal Navy. From Malta, British air and sea forces could attack Axis ships transporting vital supplies and reinforcements from Europe to the Axis forces in North Africa. Malta was one of the most intensively bombed areas during the war. The German Luftwaffe and the Italian Regia Aeronautica flew a total of 3,000 bombing raids over a period of two years. Axis plans were made for Operation Herkules, an amphibious invasion of the island supported by airborne forces, but was never carried out. In the end, Allied convoys were able to supply and reinforce Malta, though at great cost. This played a major role in the eventual Allied victory in North Africa.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Malta verloren!\n\nDie Belagerung von Malta war eine Militärkampagne im Mittelmehrraum zwischen 1940 und 1942. Die Schlacht um die Kontrolle der strategischen Insel sah die Luftwaffe und Flotte von Italien und Deutschland auf der einen, die Royal Air Force und Royal Navy auf der anderen Seite. Von Malta aus konnten britische Luft- und Seeeinheiten Schiffe der Achse angreiffen, die wichtien Nachschub sowie Verstärkung für die Truppen in Nordafrika transportierten. Malta war eines der während des Krieges am meisten bombardierten Gebiete. Die deutsche Luftwaffe und die italienische Regia Aeronautica flogen insgesamt 3000 Bombenangriffe während der 2 Jahre. Die Achsenmächte planten Operation Herkules, die Invasion der Insel unterstützt durch eine Luftlandung, jedoch wurde diese niemals ausgeführt. Schlussendlich konnten alliierte Konvois Malta versorgen und verstärken, allerdings unter schweren Verlusten. Dies war ein wichtiger Beitrag zum alliierten Sieg in Nordafrika.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Grudziadz

We have lost the battle of Grudziadz!\n\nThe Battle of Grudziadz took place from 1 September to 4 September 1939. It was a military engagement between German and Polish forces during the Invasion of Poland in 1939. The German XXI Corps assaulted the city on 1 September. The German 21st and 218th Infantry Divisions pushed back the Polish lines to the small river Ossa, east of Grudziadz. On 3 September elements of the German 45th Infantry Regiment managed to break into the town itself. The Germans held out there until the evening, but had to retreat when the Polish pressure increased. At the same time Boltuc received news that the Polish divisions on the western bank of the Vistula were facing defeat and the German forces had already crossed the Vistula in the south. This forced him to pull back his units in order to avoid being soon encircled. The Polish defenders destroyed the bridges over the Vistula and retreated to the southeast. The Germans occupied the city on 4 September.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Grudziadz verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Grudziadz fand von 1. bis 4. September 1939 statt. Das deutsche XXI Korps griff die Stadt mit der 21. und 218. Infanteriedivision an und brach am 3. durch die polnischen Linien auf die Stadt durch, mussten sich jedoch über den Fluss Ossa zurückziehen. Die Polen mussten sich nach zerstörung der Vistulabrücken zurückziehen, nachdem deutsche Verbände bereits an mehreren anderen Stellen den Fluss überschritten hatten, um der Einkreisung zu entgehen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Jaroslaw

We have lost the battle of Jaroslaw!\n\nThe Battle of Jaroslaw took place between September 10 and September 11, 1939, in the city of Jaroslaw on the San River. During the battle the Polish forces of General Stanislaw Maczek successfully held the river crossings in the town for two days against the Nazi German Wehrmacht, which was enough time for the Polish 10th Motorized Cavalry Brigade to cross the river and retreat further eastwards.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Jaroslaw verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Jaroslaw fand zwischen 10. und 11. September 1939 am Fluss San statt als General Stanislaw Maczek die Flussübergenge bei der Stadt 2 Tage lang gegen die deutschen Angreifer verteidigte, wodurch die 10. motorisierte Kavalleriebrigade sich über den Fluss zurückziehen konnte.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Kaluszyn

We have lost the battle of Kaluszyn!\n\nThe Battle of Kaluszyn, took place from September 11 to September 12, 1939. The German forces of the German 11th Infantry Division, who managed to take the town and surround the Polish forces, overran them. The Polish aim was to retake the town and break through the German encirclement before panzer reinforcements arrived and enemy resistance stiffened. The Polish forces managed to break through the positions of the enemy 44th Infantry Regiment. An order for the 4th squadron of the Polish 11th Uhlans Regiment to advance towards the town itself was mistakenly understood as an order of a cavalry charge and the squadron rushed towards the enemy positions. In the effect of the accidental charge the Poles broke through to the town. The Polish infantry followed into the breach in the German defences and by the early morning the town was liberated and the German division sent in retreat.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kaluszyn verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Kaluszyn fand am 11. und 12. September 1939 statt als die deutsche 11. Infanteriedivision von polnischen Verbänden angegriffen wurden, die die Stadt zurückerobern wollten bevor deutsche Panzerverbände eintrafen. column2: Disastrous Battle of Lodz

We have lost the battle of Lodz!\n\nThe Battle of Lodz took place from September 6 to 8, 1939. By September 6, two Wehrmacht army groups had linked up at Lodz. While Lodz was under the control of the Wehrmacht, the 4th Panzer Division continued to advance east towards Warsaw. By September 8, the German advance stalled at the gates of Warsaw. The Polish Army launched a counterattack between Lodz and Warsaw in hopes off cutting off the German army's supply lines and recapturing the city of Lodz. After three days of bitter fighting, Germany defeated the desperate Polish counterattack. The city of Lodz was occupied by Germany on September 8, 1939. Recognizing the failed counterattack, all Polish forces were ordered to fall back, regroup in Eastern Poland for a last stand, and wait for aid from Great Britain and France, which would never come.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Lodz verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Lodz fand am 6. bis 8. September 1939 statt. 2 deutsche Heeresgruppen trafen hier zusammen und nahmen die Stadt ein, jedoch starteten die Polen einen Gegenangriff auf die Stadt um die Nachschublinien der deutschen Truppen abzuschneiden. Nach 3 Tagen verzweifelter Angriffe mussten die Polen den Plan aufgeben und alle ihre Verbände nach Ostpolen zurückziehen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Lwow

We have lost the battle of Lwow!\n\nThe Battle of Lwow was a battle for the control over the Polish city of Lwow between the Polish Army, the invading Wehrmacht and the Red Army. Soviet armoured units were pushed back after a short fight. The Soviet forces completed the encirclement of the city and joined up with the German army besieging Lwow from the west. The same day the German commander sent his envoy and demanded that the city be surrendered to Germany. When the Polish envoy replied that he had no intention of signing such a document, he was informed that the general assault was ordered on September 21 and that the city would most surely be taken. However, on September 20 the Germans left their positions to the north and south of the city, and were replaced with Soviet soldiers. On September 22, 1939, the act of surrender was signed in the suburb of Winniki.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Lwow verloren!\n\nDie Belagerung von Lwow war eine Schlacht zwischen polnischen, russischen und deutschen Truppen um die Kontrolle der Stadt Lwow. Sowjetische Panterspitzen wurden nach einem kurzen Gefecht zurückgeschlagen. Russische Truppen schlossen die Stadt dann ein und nahmen Verbindung mit den Deutschen auf, die die Stadt vom Westen belagerten. Der Deutsche Kommandeur schickte einen Unterhändler und verlangte die Übergabe der Stadt an Deutschland. Als die Polen dieses ablehnten wurden sie informiert, dass der Generalangriff für den 21. September geplant war und die Stadt sicher gestürmt werden würde. Aber am 20. verließen die Deutschen ihre Positionen im Westen und Süden der Stadt, die von russischen Truppen besetzt wurden. Am 22. September 1939 wurde die Kapitulation unterzeichnet.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Radom

We have lost the battle of Radom!\n\nThe Battle of Radom was part of the Invasion of Poland during the Second World War. It lasted from 8 September 1939 to 9 September 1939. Polish troops of the Prusy Army, under the Colonel Muzyka, defended the city of Ilza and road from Sandomierz to Radom. The Polish infantry were eventually defeated by German armoured troops and made their last stand in an ancient castle on a hill near Ilza.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Radom verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Radom während der deutschen Invasion von Polen dauerte vom 8.-9. September 1939. Polnische Truppen unter Colonel Muzyka verteidigten die Stadt Ilza und die Straße nach Radom, wurden jedoch von deutschen Panzertruppen überrannt und nach einem letzten Gefecht in einer historischen Burg in der Gegend aufgerieben.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Hong Kong

We have lost the battle of Hong Kong!\n\nThe Battle of Hong Kong took place during the Pacific campaign of World War II. It began on 8 December 1941 and ended on Christmas Day with Hong Kong, then a Crown colony, surrendering to the Empire of Japan.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Hong Kong verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Hong Kong begann am 8. Dezember und bis zum Weihnachtstag konnten die Japaner die britische Kronkolonie vollständig besetzen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Ambon

We have lost the battle of Ambon!\n\nThe Battle of Ambon took place from 30 January to 3 February 1942. Dutch and Australian forces resisted a Japanese invasion. From 6 January onwards, Japanese aircraft attacked Ambon. Allied aircraft made some sorties against the approaching Japanese fleet, with little success. The naval aviation base at Halong was soon rendered unusable by Japanese air raids, and was abandoned by the Dutch and US navies in mid-January. The first land attack on Laha occurred on the afternoon of 31 January. Japanese forces were also approaching the town of Ambon from the southwest and on 31 January, the Japanese captured the town. By the morning of 3 February, the Australians around Eri were struggling to cope with increasing air and naval attacks, wounded Australians, the influx of Dutch personnel, diminishing supplies and widespread fatigue. A Japanese flag had been seen flying on the other side of the bay, at Laha. The Allied position at Kudamati was surrendered separately at midday.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Ambon verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Ambon fand am 30. Jänner bis 3. Februar 1942 statt als holländische und australische Truppen der japanischen Invasion Widerstand leisteten. Seit dem 6. Februar flog die japanische Luftwaffe Angriffe auf Ambon. Alliierte Flieger versuchten, die Invasionsflotte anzugreifen, hatten aber wenig Erfolg. Die erste Landung bei Laha am Nachmittag des 31. Jänner war erfolgreich und bald eroberten die Japaner auch Ambon. Die alliierte Positionen bei Kudamati kapitulierten mittags am 3. Februar.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Balikpapan

We have lost the battle of Balikpapan!\n\nThe Battle of Balikpapan took place on 1 July 1945. The Australian 7th Division, composed of the 18th, 21st and 25th Infantry Brigades made an amphibious landing on the island of Borneo. Heavy bombing and shelling by Australian and US air and naval forces had preceded the landing. The Japanese were totally outnumbered and out gunned. Major operations had ceased by July 21. The 7th Division's casualties were significantly lighter than they had suffered in previous campaigns. Japan surrendered while the Australians were combing the jungle for stragglers. Following the surrender the three Brigades were committed to occupation duties until around February 1946. The 21st Brigade was detached to Makassar in the Celebes Islands to accept surrender of the Japanese forces, release POWs and maintain civil order.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Balikpapan verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Balikpapan fand am 1. Juli 1945 statt. Die australische 7. Division landete auf der Insel von Borneo nach schwerem Beschuss durch alliierte Luft- und Seestreitkräfte. Die Japaner waren stark unterlegen und bis zum 21. Juli waren die Operationen fast abgeschlossen und die Verluste der 7. Division waren viel leichter als in vorhergegangenen Operationen. Die Japaner kapitulierten kurz nach dem Ende der Schlacht.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Beirut

We have lost the battle of Beirut!\n\nThe Battle of Beirut took place on 12 July 1941 and marked the end of hostilities in the Syria-Lebanon campaign. On 8 July, even before the fall of Damour, the Vichy French commander, General Henri Dentz, had sought an armistice. At one minute past midnight on 12 July a ceasefire came into effect. For all intents and purposes, this ended the campaign and an armistice was signed on 14 July at the 'Sidney Smith Barracks' on the outskirts of the city of Acre. The triumphant entry of the Australian 7th Division into Beirut successfully established the Allied occupation of Lebanon. Beirut later became an important Allied base for Mediterranean naval operations.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Beirut verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Beirut fand am 12. Juli 1941 statt. Sie war das letzte Gefecht in der Operation von Syrien-Libanon. Die Vichytruppen in der französischen Kolonie kapitulierten und ermöglichten den Briten die Sicherung des östleichen Mittelmeeres.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Kranj

We have lost the battle of Kranj!\n\nThe Battle of Kranj took place from 9 February to 15 February 1942. The Japanese Army assaulted the northwestern front of the British colony of Singapore with a primary objective to secure a second beachhead after their successful assault at Sarimbun Beach on 8 February, in order to breach the Jurong-Kranj defence line as part of their southward thrust towards the heart of Singapore City. Defending the shoreline between the Kranj River and the Johor-Singapore Causeway was the Australian 27th Brigade. On 10 February the Japanese forces suffered their heaviest losses while moving up the Kranj River, which caused them to panic and nearly aborted the operation. However, a series of miscommunications and withdrawals by Allied forces in the ensuing battles allowed the Japanese to swiftly gain strategic footholds, which eventually led to the fall of Singapore on 15 February 1942.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Kranj verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Kranj fand vom 9. bis 15. Februar 1942 statt. Die japanische Armee griff die nordwestliche Front vor Singapur mit dem Ziel an, einen zweiten Landekopf nach der erfolgreichen Landung in der Sarimbunbucht am 8. Februar zu erhalten. Die australische 27. Brigade konnte den Japanern schwere Verluste zufügen und sie beinahe aufhalten, jedoch mussten sie schließlich die Verteidigungslinien räumen und am 15. Februar 1942 fiel Singapur schließlich.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Wau

We have lost the battle of Wau!\n\nThe Battle of Wau, 29–31 January 1943, was a battle in the New Guinea campaign of World War II. Forces of the Empire of Japan sailed from Rabaul and crossed the Solomon Sea and, despite Allied air attacks, successfully reached Lae, where they disembarked. Japanese troops then advanced overland on Wau, an Australian base that potentially threatened the Japanese positions at Salamaua and Lae. A race developed between the Japanese moving overland, hampered by the terrain, and the Australians, moving by air, hampered by the weather. By the time the Japanese reached the Wau area after a trek over the mountains, the Australian defenders had been greatly reinforced by air. In the battle that followed, despite achieving tactical surprise by approaching from an unexpected direction, the Japanese attackers were unable to capture Wau.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Wau verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Wai vom 29–31. Jänner 1943 war Teil der Operationen auf Neuguinea. Japanische Truppen überquerten die Solomonensee von Rabaul und landeten trotz alliierter Luftangriffe bei Lae, wonach sie auf dem Landweg nach Wau, einer australischen Basis, vorstießen. Ein Rennen entstand zwischen japanischen Truppen auf dem Landweg und australischen Verstärkungen auf dem Luftweg. Beide Seiten wurden durch das Gelände und Wetter behindert. Als die Japaner Wau erreichten konnten sie die Australier zwar überraschen, jedoch waren diese so stark verstärkt worden, dass ihnen die Eroberung der Basis nicht gelang.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Singapore

We have lost the battle of Singapore!\n\nThe Battle of Singapore was fought in the southeast Asian theatre of World War II when the Empire of Japan invaded the Allied stronghold of Singapore. Singapore was the major British military base in South East Asia and nicknamed the 'Gibraltar of the East'. The fighting in Singapore lasted from 8 December 1941 to 15 February 1942. It resulted in the fall of Singapore to the Japanese, and the largest surrender of British-led military personnel in history. About 80,000 British, Australian and Indian troops became prisoners of war, joining 50,000 taken by the Japanese in the Malayan campaign. Britain's Prime Minister Winston Churchill called the ignominious fall of Singapore to the Japanese the 'worst disaster' and 'largest capitulation' in British history.
column4: 'Wir haben die Schlacht von Singapur verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Singapur dauerte vom 8. Dezember 1941 bis 15. Februar 1942. Sie resultierte im Fall von Singapur, dem 'Gibraltar des Pazifik', der wichtigsten britischen Basis in dem Gebiet. Es war die größte Kapitulation von british geführten Truppen in der Geschichte. Etwa 80000 Briten, Australier und Inder gingen in Gefangenschaft.'

column2: Disastrous Battle of Tarakan

We have lost the battle of Tarakan!\n\nThe Battle of Tarakan was the first stage in the Borneo campaign of 1945. It began with an amphibious landing by Australian forces on 1 May, code-named Operation Oboe One. While the battle ended with success for the Allied forces over the Japanese defenders, this victory is generally regarded as having not justified its costs.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Tarakan verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Tarakan war die erste Stufe in der Operation auf Borneo 1945. Am 1. Mai landeten australische Truppen in der Operation Oboe One und schlugen die Japaner in der Schlacht, jedoch mit hohen Verlusten, von denen man generell sagt dass sie es nicht wert waren.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Berlin

We have lost the battle of Berlin!\n\nThe Battle in Berlin dealt with the ever tightening ring around the German capital. The outcome of the Battle in Berlin was decided during the initial phases of the Battle of Berlin that took place outside the city. As the Soviets invested Berlin and the German forces placed to stop them were destroyed or forced back, the city's fate was sealed. Nevertheless, there was much heavy fighting within the city of Berlin as the Red Army fought its way, street by street, through to the centre of the city. On 23 April 1945, the first Soviet ground forces started to penetrate the outer suburbs of Berlin. By 27 April, Berlin was completely cut off from the outside world. The battle in the city continued until 2 May 1945. On that date, the commander of the Berlin Defence Area, General Helmuth Weidling, surrendered to the commander of the Soviet 8th Guards Army, Lieutenant-General Vasily Chuikov. Chuikov was a constituent of Marshal Georgiy Zhukov's 1st Belorussian Front.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Berlin verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Berlin am Ende des 2. Weltkrieges war bereits entschieden, bevor die Stadt von russischen Truppen eingeschlossen wurde, als die deutschen Truppen, die die Stadt decken sollten, außerhalb der Stadt zerschlagen wurden. Es gab jedoch in der gesamten Stadt heftige Gefechte bis die Russen am 23. April 1945 in die Vorstädte eindrangen. Am 27. April war Berlin komplett abgeschnitten und die Schlacht ging bis 2. Mai weiter, bis der deutsche General Helmuth Weidling die Kapitulation unterzeichnete.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Pegu

We have lost the battle of Pegu!\n\nThe Battle of Pegu took place from 3 March to 7 March 1942. Japanese forces closed in on the British Indian Army who was deployed near Pegu. The 'B' Squadron of the 7th Hussars arrived in the village of Payagyi to find the Japanese already there. A confused battle ensued. Then the order came for the British to move to Hlegu. Hlegu was also in Japanese hands as the British approached. The Japanese had erected a roadblock and they defended it with molotov cocktails. In the end, they were forced to retreat in the face of heavy fire from the tanks. General Alexander had realised that Rangoon was doomed, and his new plan involved a withdrawal to Prome, some 200 miles to the north. The objective, to convince the Japanese that Rangoon would be defended, had been achieved. The British Indian Army moved on to Taukkyan that evening.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Pegu verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Pegu fand von 3. bis 7. März 1942 statt als japanische Truppen die britisch-indische Armee bei Pegu angriff. Nachdem britische Panzer eingriffen wurden die Japaner zurückgedrängt. General Alexander war klar dass Rangun nicht zu halten war und zog sich nach Prome in Norden zurück. Das Ziel die Japaner zu überzeugen dass Rangun verteidigt würde war erreicht worden.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Tampere

We have lost the battle of Tampere!\n\nThe Battle of Tampere of the Finnish Civil War was fought in Finland in 1918 between Red and White forces. The White forces besieged and captured the main city of the Red Guards, Tampere, taking 10,000 Red prisoners.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Tampere verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Tampere im finnischen Bürgerkrieg wurde 1918 zwischen roten und weißen Truppen ausgefochten. Die weißen Truppen belagerten die Stadt und nahmen sie schließlich ein, wobei sie 10000 rote Gefangene machten.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Wilno

We have lost the battle of Wilno!\n\nThe Battle of Wilno was one of the major battles during the Soviet invasion of Poland that accompanied the larger German invasion. During the days of 18-19 September, the Soviet forces approached and took over the major city of Wilno. The Polish forces in the area were relatively weak and the Polish commanders, unsure whether to actively oppose the Soviets, did not utilise the full defensive capabilities of the town and nearby fortified areas, although the outcome of the battle could not be any different, given the overwhelming Soviet numerical superiority.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Wilno verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Wilno war eines der letzten größeren Gefechte während des russischen Einmarsches in Polen 1939. Während des 18-19. September nahmen sowjetische Truppen die Stadt gegen relativ schwachen polnischen Widerstand ein da die polnischen Kommandeure nicht sicher waren, ob sie den Russen Widerstand entgegensetzen sollten.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Palmyra

We have lost the battle of Palmyra!\n\nThe Battle of Palmyra was part of the Allied invasion of Syria during the Syria-Lebanon campaign. The Habforce set off on June 21 and surrounded Palmyra. On June 28 they captured the French fort of Seba' Biyar, the small garrison surrendering without a shot fired, and the next day they occupied Sukhna. On the morning of July 1 Sukhna was attacked by the Vichy 2nd Light Desert Company. The Arab Legion occupiers had been reinforced by a squadron from 4th Cavalry Brigade's Household Cavalry Regiment and after a sharp battle, the French retreated and ended up trapped in a box valley before surrendering. Whilst hardly the largest battle of the war, its effect was to cause the 3rd Light Desert Company to lose heart and they surrendered Palmyra on the night of 2 July.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Palmyra verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Palmyra war Teil der alliierten Invasion von Syrien. Die Habforce umkreiste Palmyra am 21. Juni und nach einigen harten Kämpfen mit der Vichy-Garnison kapitulierte die Stadt schließlich am 2. Juli.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Leningrad

We have lost the battle of Leningrad!\n\nThe Siege of Leningrad took place from 8 September 1941 to 27 January 1944. It was one of the longest and most destructive sieges in history and the most costly in terms of casualties. It caused the greatest destruction and the largest loss of life ever known in a modern city. Most of the palaces of the Tsars and other historic landmarks located outside the city's defensive perimeter were looted and then destroyed. A number of factories, schools, hospitals and other civil infrastructure were destroyed by air raids and long-range artillery bombardment. The siege resulted in the deaths of up to 1,500,000 soldiers and civilians and the evacuation of 1,400. Civilians in the city suffered from extreme starvation. In January-February of 1942 about 7000 - 10 000 citizens died every day, most of them from hunger.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Leningrad verloren!\n\nDie Belagerung von Leningrad dauerte vom 8. September 1941 bis zum 27. Jänner 1944. Sie war eine der längsten und zerstörerischten Belagerungen der Geschichte und die mit den meisten Verlusten. Sie kostete die meiste Zerstörung und die größten Verluste in einer modernen Stadt. Die meisten Zarenpaläste und andere historische Gebäude außerhalb des Verteidigungsringes wurden geplündert und zerstört. Eine Anzahl von Fabriken, Schulen, Spitäler und andere zivile Einrichtungen wurden durch Luftantriffe oder Artillerie vernichtet. Die Belagerung führte zum Tod von bis zu 1,5 Millionen Soldaten und Zivilisten und der Evakuierung von 1,4 Millionen. Zivilisten in der Stadt hungerten. Im Jänner-Februar 1941 starben etwa 7000-10000 Menschen jeden Tag, die meisten davon am Hunger.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Iwo Jima

We have lost the battle of Iwo Jima!\n\nThe Battle of Iwo Jima took place from February 19 to March 26, 1945. The United States fought for and captured Iwo Jima from Japan. The Japanese positions on the island were heavily fortified, with vast bunkers, hidden artillery, and 18 km of underground tunnels. The Americans were covered by extensive naval and air support, capable of putting an enormous amount of firepower onto the Japanese positions. The U.S. invasion was charged with the mission of capturing the two airfields on Iwo Jima. Despite heavy fighting and casualties on both sides, Japanese defeat was assured from the start. The Americans possessed an overwhelming superiority in arms and numbers - this, coupled with the impossibility of Japanese retreat or reinforcement, ensured that there was no plausible scenario in which the United States could have lost the battle.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Iwo Jima verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Iwo Jima fand vom 19. Februar bis 26. März 1945 statt. Die USA nahmen die Insel von Japan ein, die mit starken Befestigungen, unterirdischen Gängen von 18km Länge, versteckten Artilleriestellungen und anderen Positionen durchzogen war. Unter starkem Luft- und Seebeschuss überlebten nur 216 der 18000 japanischen Verteidiger. Der Ausgang der Schlacht war aufgrund der übermächtigen Stärke der US Truppen nie in Frage gestellt.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Dakar

We have lost the battle of Dakar!\n\nThe Battle of Dakar was an unsuccessful attempt in September 1940 by the Allies to capture the strategic port of Dakar in French West Africa. The Allies decided to send a naval force of an aircraft carrier, two battleships, five cruisers, and ten destroyers to Dakar. The Allied fleet attacked the coastal defences, and the Vichy forces defended them. Overall, the Battle of Dakar did not go well for the Allies. The Vichy forces did not back down. During most of this conflict, bombers of the Vichy French Air Force based in North Africa bombed the British base at Gibraltar. On September 24 about 50 aircraft dropped 150 bombs while on September 25 about 100 aircraft dropped 300 bombs on the harbor and dockyards. Most of the bombs missed. Some damage but few casualties were caused. Finally, the Allies withdrew, leaving Dakar and French West Africa in Vichy hands.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Dakar verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Dakar war ein fehlgeschlagener Versuch der Alliierten im September 1940 den strategischen Hafen von Dakar an der westafrikanischen Küste zu erobern. Die Alliierten entsandten einen Träger, 2 Schlachtschiffe, 5 Kreuzer und 10 Zerstörer. Die Vichy-Verteidiger lehnten die Übergabe ab und konnten erfolgreich alle Angriffe abwehren, bis die Alliierten schließlich aufgaben und ihre Flotte zurückzogen.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Nanchang

We have lost the battle of Nanchang!\n\nThe Battle of Nanchang was the first major conflict to occur following the Chinese defeat at the Battle of Wuhan. Nanchang was a railway center, the major supply line between the 3rd and 9th Military Regions, and site of the airbase threatening Japanese shipping in Yangtze River. By March 27, Nanchang had fallen after being surrounded and put under siege by Japanese forces. During a period lasting until the end of April some Japanese forces were moved to support operations in other areas. This weakening of available Japanese manpower had consequences. On April 21, a surprise attack by the forces of the 3rd and 9th Military Regions allowed for a breakthrough by the 32nd Army Group that allowed a Chinese spearhead to reach the outer area of Nanchang in 5 days. However, under heavy attack from Japanese Aviation and facing a Japanese garrison re-enforced by components of the Navy they were unable to lay an effective siege and retreated on May 9.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Nanchang verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Nanchang war das erste große Gefecht nach der chinesischen Niederlage in der Schlacht von Wuhan. Nanchang war ein Eisenbahnzentrum sowie ein wichtiger Luftstützpunkt für Angriffe auf die japanische Schifffahrt auf dem Jangtze. Am 27. März war die Stadt gefallen, nachdem sie von japanischen Truppen eingeschlossen und belagert wurde. Bis April wurden einige japanische Truppen verlegt und so konnten die Chinesen durch einen überaschenden Gegenangriff die Stadt ihrerseite einschließen, wurden jedoch von der starken Garnison und der japanischen Luftüberlegenheit zurückgeschlagen und mussten am 9. Mai zurückweichen.

column2: Disastrous First Battle of Guam

We have lost the first battle of Guam!\n\nThe First Battle of Guam took place from December 8 to December 10, 1941 between Japanese and American forces. On December 8, Japanese aircraft from Saipan attacked Guam. On December 10, the 5th Company landed on Dungcas Beach on Agana Bay north of Agana, attacked and quickly captured the Insular Force Guard in Agana. It then advanced on Piti moving toward Sumay and the Marine Barracks. The South Seas Detachment began landing on the north flank of Tumon Bay on the upper northwest coast and moved towards Agana. The principal engagement took place on Agana's Plaza de Espana when a few Marines and Insuler Force Guardsmen fought with the 5th Company. After token resistance, the Marines and Governor McMillin surrendered. No further fighting took place, but a few skirmishes took place all over the island before news of the surrender spread and the rest of the island forces surrendered as well.
column4: Wir haben die erste Schlacht von Guam verloren!\n\nDie erste Schlacht von Guam fand am 8. Dezember 1941 statt als zuerst japanische Flugzeuge von Saipan die amerikanische Insel angriffen und am 10. landeten die ersten japanischen Truppen in der Aganabucht. Nach geringem Widerstand durch US Marines kapitulierte Governor McMillin offiziell.

column2: Disastrous Second Battle of Guam

We have lost the second battle of Guam!\n\nThe Second Battle of Guam took place from July 21 to August 8, 1944 and was the American capture of the Japanese held island of Guam during the Pacific campaign of World War II. On July 21 the Americans landed on both sides of the Orote peninsula on the western side of Guam. Japanese counter-attacks were made throughout the first few days of the battle, mostly at night, using infiltration tactics. Several times they penetrated the American defences and were driven back with heavy loss of men and equipment. The counterattacks around the American beachheads had exhausted the Japanese. At the start of August they were running out of food and ammunition and had only a handful of tanks left. After an engagement at Mount Barrigada from August 2 to August 4, the Japanese line collapsed and the rest of the battle was a pursuit to the north. As in other battles of the Pacific War, the Japanese refused to surrender, and almost all were killed.
column4: Wir haben die zweite Schlacht von Guam verloren!\n\nDie zweite Schlacht von Guam fand zwischen 21. Juli bis 8. August 1944 statt und beschreibt die amerikanische Landung auf die japanisch besetzte Insel. Nach der Landung der Amerikaner führten die Japaner fast jede Nacht Gegenangriffe durch und durchstießen dabei häufig die US Linien, wurden jedoch jeweils unter hohen Verlusten zurückgeschlagen. Anfang August waren die Japaner fast ohne Nahrung und Munition und hatten nur mehr eine Handvoll Panzer. Wie in den anderen Schlachten im Pazifik lehnten die Japaner aber bis zuletzt jede Kapitulation ab und fast alle starben.

column2: Disastrous Battle of Rabaul

We have lost the battle of Rabaul!\n\nThe Battle of Rabaul took place in January and February 1942. In January 1942, Rabaul came under attack by large numbers of Japanese carrier based aircraft. On 21 January, eight Wirraways attacked a formation of 109 Japanese aircraft, three RAAF planes were shot down, two crash-landed, and another was damaged. As a result of the intense air attacks, Australian coastal artillery was destroyed and Australian infantry were withdrawn from Rabaul itself. Rabaul became the biggest Japanese base in New Guinea. The Australians tried to restrict its development soon after its capture by a bombing counter attack in March. In December 1943, during the Battle of Cape Gloucester, U.S. Marines landed in western New Britain and consequent Allied operations on New Britain gradually restricted the Japanese force to Rabaul. However, a large number of Japanese personnel remained in Rabaul until the Japanese surrender in August 1945.
column4: Wir haben die Schlacht von Rabaul verloren!\n\nDie Schlacht von Rabaul fand im Jänner und Februar 1942 statt, als die Stadt von japanischen Flugzeugen intesiv bombardiert wurde und dadurch die australischen Truppen zum Rückzug gezwungen wurden. Rabaul wurde zur größten japanischen Basis in Neuguinea.US Marines landeten im Westen von Neubrittanien und drängten die Japaner langsam auf Rabaul zurück, jedoch konnten sie die Basis selbst bis zur Kapitulation im August 1945 halten.

column2: Disastrous First Battle of Changsha

We have lost the first battle of Changsha!\n\nThe First Battle of Changsha took place from September 17, 1939 to October 6, 1939 and was the first attempt by Japan to take the city of Changsha, China. The Japanese launched the attacks on September 17, when their forces in northern Jiangxi attacked westward toward Henan. However, the Japanese stretched too far out westward and were counter-attacked by Chinese forces from the south and the north, forcing them to retreat eastward. On September 23 the Japanese drove the Chinese out of the Sinchiang river area. Heavy fighting continued after the 23rd and the Chinese retreated southward to attract the Japanese while supporting battalions arrived on the east and the west for encirclement maneuver. On September 29 the Japanese reached the outskirts of Changsha. However, they were unable to conquer the city because the Chinese cut off their supply lines. By October 6 the Japanese forces at Changsha were decimated while the remnants retreated northward.
column4: Wir haben die erste Schlacht von Changsha verloren!\n\nDie erste Schlacht von Changsha fand vom 17. September bis 6. Oktober 1939 statt und war der erste japanische Versuch, die Stadt einzunehmen. Japanische Truppen im Norden von Jiangxi griffen westlich in Richtung Henan an. Jedoch stießen sie zu weit vor und wurden durch einen chinesischen Gegenangriff zurückgeschlacgen. Ein zweiter Angriff erreichte den Rand von Changsha, jedoch wurden die japanischen Nachschublinien abgeschnitten und die Japaner mussten sich nach schweren Verlusten zurückziehen.

column2: Disastrous Second Battle of Changsha

We have lost the second battle of Changsha!\n\nThe Second Battle of Changsha took place from September 6 to October 8, 1941 and was Japan's second attempt in taking the city of Changsha. The battle started when a small Chinese guerrilla force clashed with the Japanese 6th Division in the mountains southeast of Yueyang on September 6th. On the 17th, the Japanese crossed the Sinchiang River at four points and made rapid advances, crossing the Milo River on the 19th. The main Chinese force avoided confronting the enemy but marched in a parallel fashion flanking the Japanese trail southward. The Chinese and the Japanese army reached the Laotao River regions for an inevitable battle. On September 27th, several hundred Japanese troops in plain clothes reached the north gate of Changsha but were unable to sabotage the city defences, leading to heavy fighting on the 28th. Unable to overcome the defenders, the Japanese began a general retreat back to the Yueyang region on September 30th.
column4: Wir haben die zweite Schlacht von Changsha verloren!\n\nDie zweite Schlacht von Changsha fand vom 6. September bis 8. Oktober 1941 statt und war der zweite japanische Versuch, die Stadt zu erobern. Eine kleine chinesische Guerilliaeinheit startete ein Gefecht mit der japanischen 6. Division in den Bergen südöstlich von Yueyang.  Am 17. September überquerten die Japaner den Fluss Sinchiang an 4 verschiedenen Stellen und stießen rasch vor. Die Hauptkräfte der Chinesen griffen die Japaner nicht direkt an, sondern marschierten an ihren Flanken parallel zum Vormarsch, bis es bei der Stadt Changsha zur Schlacht kam. Die Japaner zogen sich zurück, nachdem sie nicht in der Lage waren, den Verteidigungsring um die Stadt zu durchbrechen.

column2: Disastrous Third Battle of Changsha

We have lost the third battle of Changsha!\n\nThe Third Battle of Changsha was the third attempt by the Japanese to invade the Chinese province of Hunan. In June 1944 the Japanese deployed 360,000 troops to invade Changsha. On 27th May, 1944, the Japanese 11th Army launched the 1944 general offensive toward Changsha as scheduled. The Japanese flanked the Chinese troops defending Changsha and cut off their possible retreat routes, and placed some secondary divisions in charge of attacking Changsha. The Chinese attempted to use the previous tactic of avoid direct contact by marching in parallel fashion to flank the Japanese, but were unable to encircle the enemy like before and had to retreat. This allowed IJA to rapidly ransack the city of Changsha, breaking the defences of the infantry within the city, as well as neutralizing the Chinese artillery on Yuelu Mountain, and Changsha was quickly lost to the Japanese.
column4: Wir haben die dritte Schlacht von Changsha verloren!\n\nDie dritte Schlacht von Changsha war der dritter japanische Versuch, die chinesische Provinz von Hunan einzunehmen. Im Juni 1944 griffen 360000 Japaner die Stadt Changsha an und am 27. Mai startete die japanische 11. Armee die Offensive. Die chinesischen Verteidiger wurden umgangen und eigekreist. Die Chinesen versuchten, wie in der 2. Schlacht die Japanischen Angriffstruppen zu flankieren, konnten dies jedoch nicht erreichen und mussten sich zurückziehen. Die Japaner nahmen daraufhin die Stadt ein.

column2: Disastrous Battle
The Battle has been lost
Effective Bombing of Wielun

The bombing of Wielun refers to the indiscriminate bombing of the Polish town of Wielun by the German Luftwaffe on 1 September 1939. The Luftwaffe started bombing Wielun five minutes before the shelling of Westerplatte, which has traditionally been considered the beginning of World War II. It is considered to be one of the first terror bombings in history and first in Europe in this war. It killed an estimated 1300 civilians, injured hundreds more and destroyed 90 percent of the town centre. It is widely acknowledged that there were no targets of any importance in the area such as military installations or industrial facilities. The casualty rate was more than twice as high as Guernica.
column4: Die Bombardierung von Wielun war der Angriff der Luftwaffe auf die polnische Stadt Wielun am 1. September 1939. Die Luftwaffe begann mit dem Angriff 5 Minuten vor dem Beginn der Beschießung der Westerplatte, welche üblicherweise als Beginn des 2. Weltkrieges galt. 1300 Zivilisten kamen bei einem der ersten Terror-Bombardements zum Leben, dem ersten in Europa. Hunderte weitere wurden verletzt ung 90 Prozent des Stadtzentrums wurden zerstört. In der Stadt befanden sich keine wichtigen militärischen oder industriellen Ziele. Die Verlustrate war mehr als doppelt so hoch als in Guernica.

column2: This is a day to remember!
column4: Dieser Tag soll nie vergessen werden!

column2: Great work men!
Effective Bombing of Guernica

The bombing of Guernica took place on April 26, 1937 and was an aerial attack on the Basque town of Guernica, causing widespread destruction and civilian deaths during the Spanish Civil War. The raid by planes of the German Luftwaffe 'Condor Legion' and the Italian Fascist Aviazione Legionaria was called Operation Rügen. The Basque government reported 1,654 people killed, but modern research suggests between 200 to 400 civilians died. Western countries viewed Guernica as an example of terror bombing and gained the impression that the Luftwaffe was committed to that tactic. The bombing was the subject of a famous anti-war painting by Pablo Picasso.
column4: 'Die Bombardierung von Guernica fand am 26. April 1937 statt, als Flugzeuge der deutschen 'Legion Condor' die baskische Stadt angriffen und große Zerstörung von viele zivile Opfer verursachten.Operation Rügen, wie der Angriff bezeichnet wurde, verursachte laut der baskischen Regierung 1654 Tote, moderne Nachforschungen gehen jedoch eher von 200 bis 400 toten Zivilisten aus. Westliche Länder sahen Guernica als Terror-Bombardement an und gewannen den Eindruck, dass dies die Taktik der deutschen Luftwaffe war. Die Operation wurde von Pablo Picasso in einem berühmten Antikriegsgemälde behandelt..'

column2: Effective Bombing of London

The Battle of Britain was the air campaign waged by the German Air Force against the United Kingdom during the summer and autumn of 1940. The Battle of Britain was the first major campaign to be fought entirely by air forces, and was the largest and most sustained aerial bombing campaign until that date. From July 1940 coastal shipping convoys and shipping centres, such as Portsmouth were the main targets, one month later the Luftwaffe shifted its attacks to RAF airfields and infrastructure. As the battle progressed the Luftwaffe also targeted aircraft factories and ground infrastructure. Eventually the Luftwaffe resorted to attacking areas of political significance and using terror bombing tactics. The failure of Germany to achieve its objectives of destroying Britain's air defences, or forcing Britain to negotiate an armistice or an outright surrender is considered its first major defeat and one of the crucial turning points in the war.
column4: Die Luftschlacht um England war die Offensive der deutschen Luftwaffe gegen England im Sommer und Herbst 1940. Sie war die erste Offensive, die ausschließlich von Luftstreitkrägten ausgetragen wurden und war längste kontinuierliche Bombenoffensive bis zu diesem Datum. Von Juli 1940 an wurden Küstenkonvois und Hafenanlagen wie in Portsmouth hauptsächlich angegriffen, einen Monat später waren Flugplätze und Infrastruktur der RAF das Hauptziel der Luftwaffe. Im Verlauf der Offensive wurden auch die Flugzeugindustrie und Bodeninfrastruktur angegriffen. Schließlich ging die Luftwaffe zu Angriffen auf Ziele mit politischer Bedeutung und Terrorbombardements über. Das Fehlschlagen der deutschen Offensive war der erste richtige Rückschlag im Krieg und wird als einer der wichtigsten Wendepunkte im Krieg angesehen.

column2: Effective Bombing of Chongqing

The bombing of Chongqing took place from 18 February 1938 to 23 August 1943 and was part of an Imperial Japanese Army Air Service and Imperial Japanese Navy Air Service terror bombing operation on the Chinese provisional capital of Chongqing. A conservative estimate places the number of bombing runs at more than 5,000, with more than 11,500 bombs dropped, mainly incendiary bombs. The bombing of Chongqing was focused almost entirely on the civilian population. In the first two days of the campaign, the raids of May 1939 killed more than five thousand Chinese civilians. Two months later, after tens of thousands of deaths, in retaliation for firebombing, the United States embargoed the export of airplane parts to Japan, thus imposing its first economic sanction against Japan. Three thousand tons of bombs were launched on the city between 1939 and 1942. A total of 268 air raids were conducted against Chongqing.
column4: Die Bombardierung von Chongqing durch die kaiserlich japanische Luftwaffe und Marineluftwaffe zwischen 18. Februar 1938 und 23. August 1943 war eine Terrobombardierung der provisorischen chinesischen Hauptstadt. Mehr als 11500 hauptsächlich Brandbomben wurden während mehr als 5000 Angriffen abgeworfen. Die Angriffe waren aus ausschließlich auf die Zivilbevölkerung gerichtet. In den erssten 2 Tagen wurden über 5000 Chinesen getötet. Nach 2 Monaten und mehreren zehntausend Opfern verhängten die USA ein Embargo auf den Export von Flugzeugteilen, die erste wirtschaftliche Sanktion gegen Japan. Zwischen 1939uand 1942 wurden über 3000 Tonnen Bomben in 268 Luftangriffen auf die Stadt abgeworfen.

column2: Effective Bombing of Berlin

The Air Battle of Berlin took place from November 1943 to March 1944. Between November 1943 and March 1944 Bomber Command made 16 massed attacks on Berlin. The Battle of Berlin was a failure for the Royal Air Force as it was not the knockout blow that Harris had predicted and during the battle, the RAF lost 1,047 bombers, with a further 1,682 damaged, and well over 7,000 aircrew, culminating in the raid on Nuremberg on 30 March 1944, when 94 bombers were shot down and 71 damaged, out of 795 aircraft. There were many other raids on Berlin by the RAF and the USAAF Eighth Air Force in the strategic bombing campaign of 1940–1945 and this is reflected in the RAF battle honour, which is for bombardment of Berlin, by aircraft of Bomber Command 1940–1945. Prior to the battle of Berlin, Berlin had been subject to a large raid on 23/24 August of 700+ aircraft. A raid half that size, losing 7% of the aircraft, had taken place in September.
column4: Die Luftschlacht um Berlin fand zwischen November 1943 und März 1944 statt. In diesem Zeitraum führte das Bomber Command 16 massierte Angriffe auf die Stadt durch, sie waren jedoch ein kostspieliger Fehlschlag und wurden nicht zum entscheidenden Schlag, den Harris vorausgesagt hatte. Während der Angriffe gingen 1047 bombers verloren, weitere 1682 waren beschädigt, und weiter über 7000 Flieger starben. Beim Angriff auf Nürnberg am 30. März 1944 gingen 94 Bomber von 700 verloren während 71 weitere beschädigt wurden. Berlin wurde noch oft von britischen und amerikanischen Flugzeugen angegriffen.

column2: Effective Bombing of Helsinki

Helsinki was bombed several times during World War II. Finland fought three wars between 1939–1945, two against the Soviet Union and one against Germany. The largest raids were three raids in February 1944, which have been called the Great raids against Helsinki. Helsinki's air defences prioritised stopping bombs from reaching the city over the destruction of air targets.
